Headings.text: You need to empower and energise others
Motivating others is a key leadership skill
It all starts with how you communicate
As you inspire, so you will influence
To make people want to do their best
To create vision and execute the mission
To gain the respect of those you lead
People will be inspired to follow you
You will lead from values and purpose
Your team and results will flourish

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: What actually motivates us?  Psychology, behavioural research and sociology all come at this question from many different angles...

Videos.name: The Motivation Checklist
Videos.description: 'More than anything else, employees want to be valued for a job well done by those they hold in high esteem'...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Martin Luther King, Jr. had a dream. Nelson Mandela had a cause. Mohandas Ghandi fought for freedom. These iconic leaders all had one thing common -Purpose...

Videos.name: Inspiration and Craft
Videos.description: There are no sure fire formulas to inspiration but there are some principles that can guide you in the right direction and some tools that can help you craft a way of “being inspirational”...

Videos.name: Motivation & Inspiration Call to Action
Videos.description: As leaders, we can start to take responsibility for all the factors that are in our control, let go of the factors that aren’t, and maintain our own sense of motivation in the face of challenges.  Easier said than done...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: The GROW model is used a great deal in coaching, management and problem solving. This video introduces the four stages of the model...

Videos.name: The GROW Model Goal
Videos.description: Stage One of the GROW model is about the goal and how to set about establishing it...

Videos.name: The GROW Model Reality
Videos.description: Stage Two of the GROW model is about a person's reality and how to establish where someone is in relation to where they want to be...

Videos.name: The GROW Model Options
Videos.description: Stage Three of the GROW model is the brainstorming stage and all about possibility...

Videos.name: The GROW Model Way Forward
Videos.description: Stage Four is the final stage of the GROW model and is all about helping the person to establish the actions they now need to take...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: One of the options a leader has is to allow an individual to choose how they go about doing their work.  This video also looks at why being a micro-manager can be a major de-motivator...

Videos.name: Diversity and Respect
Videos.description: In order to inspire and motivate a team you must first have a deep understanding of who they are so that you can build rapport, trust and respect...

Videos.name: Learning Styles and Motivation
Videos.description: Not everyone learns in the same way - figuring out how different team members learn will greatly assist your leadership of them...

Videos.name: Giving Feedback
Videos.description: Giving constructive and effective feedback is a key role of the leader.  This video illustrates how to get the best outcomes...

Videos.name: Listening with Empathy
Videos.description: A reminder of the vital importance of listening properly, what it looks like and how to do it with empathy.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: Now is the time when you get to practise motivating and inspiring your team.  We've given you a lot of tools, but how do you start implementing them?  This video has some suggestions.

Courses.intro_description: Leaders who motivate and inspire, create a climate in which people want to do their best.  They can assess people's strengths and use those strengths to get the most from them.  And they can do so in good times and bad times.  If you want to get more from the people you lead, take a look at the following videos.
Courses.name: The Inspirational Leader
Courses.description: Learn how to inspire the people you lead.

Headings.text: Dynamic leadership is a learned skill
Match your actions to your values
You will know how to lead inspirationally
You will be seen as an effective leader

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: What happens when a leader communicates, and how people interpret what is being said, is a complex process.  This video will help you get to grips with the Shannon-Weaver model of communication.

Videos.name: Decoding Messages
Videos.description: Decoding the values of others is easier than you think - if you learn to decipher the signs...

Videos.name: Encoding Messages Through Storytelling
Videos.description: All of us will have had the experience of communicating brilliantly - but the key is to understand how we did it so that we can repeat it at will...

Videos.name: Defining Impact and Presence
Videos.description: People will forget what you said and even what you did, but they will never forget how you made them feel...

Videos.name: Values-Based Leadership
Videos.description: A leader's values are a reflection of who they are – and, more importantly, who they want to be as a leader...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Authentic presence is impossible to fake and is no accident...

Videos.name: The Storytelling Format
Videos.description: The difference between a compelling story and a formless anecdote very often lies less in the basic content.  What should it be?

Videos.name: Choose Your Story
Videos.description: We’ve been telling stories for centuries and don’t have to go back far to understand the powerful effect storytelling has on our hearts and minds...

Videos.name: The Power of Sensory Language
Videos.description: Sensory language inspires listeners to consider concepts and consequences in a much more three-dimensional way.  This is a simple skill to learn...

Videos.name: Declarative vs Narrative Language
Videos.description: This video shows perfectly the difference between declarative and narrative language and how the latter can be used to have a lasting impact on your audience.

Videos.name: The Key to Leadership Presence
Videos.description: Effective and Congruent communication skills are the keys to authentic Leadership presence. Here's a mini toolkit of tips to use and practice to enhance yours...

Videos.name: Giving One Thought Per Person
Videos.description: Defining messages so an audience really connects with them is one of the keys to maintaining positive presence in any meeting or interaction...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Even great leaders have to face pressures, awkward situations, and seemingly overwhelming challenges.  Here we look at the key to effective and successful leadership...

Videos.name: Outcome Thinking
Videos.description: Outcome thinking is what separates effective leaders from ineffective leaders...

Videos.name: The Decision to Act
Videos.description: Here we outline two of the key influencing strategies that can be used to sell ideas that motivate people - social proof and the rule of commitment...

Videos.name: Building Rapport
Videos.description: Robert Cialdini, a leading researcher in the study of Influence, states that we are more likely to be influenced by people that we like or have rapport with...

Videos.name: Putting it all Together
Videos.description: Leadership Presence is a state of listening and responsiveness and Impact is the effect you have on those around you.  Here's a reminder of some of the key techniques we've been talking about and how to put them all together...

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: Thank of a leader who had a positive impact on your life, personally or professionally.  How did they make you feel and what did they do to make such an impact?

Courses.intro_description: We want our leaders to make a lasting impact on us and have a presence that inspires us to follow them.  These videos show you how to engage people, be credible and have that elusive quality of leaders - gravitas.
Courses.name: Leading with Impact and Presence
Courses.description: Command the respect of people around you through powerful communication.

Headings.text: Your brand is what you stand for
Brand affects your sphere of influence
It's the way people perceive you
How to create your personal brand
People will perceive you in the best light
Your leadership brand will be functional
You behaviour will work in your favour

Videos.name: What is Personal Brand?
Videos.description: Personal Brand is what others say about you when you're not in the room. This course of videos is about making sure what they say is favourable...

Chapters.name: Personal Impact, Image and Brand - The Differences

Videos.name: Personal Impact, Image and Brand - The Differences
Videos.description: This video is a reminder of how Personal Brand differs from Personal Impact and Personal Image...

Videos.name: How to be Perceived Well
Videos.description: Virtually everyone wishes to be perceived well. Here are some steps you can take to start the process...

Videos.name: The Law of Authenticity
Videos.description: Everyone likes people who are authentic.  This video explores this idea...

Videos.name: The Law of Reputation
Videos.description: Every action and interaction will affect a person's reputation either positively or negatively.  Here are some tips around how to nurture and protect your reputation...

Videos.name: The Law of Distinction
Videos.description: Many business people try to be quite good at most things but forget to be truly outstanding at one or two key skills that would really make them stand out...

Videos.name: The Law of Goodwill
Videos.description: The law of goodwill is about building effective partnerships through generosity and reciprocity...

Videos.name: The Law of Visibility
Videos.description: To be successful, your personal brand must be seen over and over again, until it imprints itself on the consciousness of its domain or sphere of influence...

Videos.name: The Law of Leadership
Videos.description: Leadership is for everyone and anyone can work to exhibit leadership behaviours to help them become the leaders of tomorrow...

Videos.name: The Law of First Impressions
Videos.description: It's well known that a strong first impression can really help oil the wheels of a good relationship. This video explains how to create the best possible first impression...

Videos.name: Creating Your Brand
Videos.description: Individual values lie at the foundation of any effective personal brand and this video discusses why it's important to choose yours carefully...

Videos.name: Accountability
Videos.description: Accountability—in the communications sense— means taking responsibilityfor what you say. It also means doing what you say you’ll do, taking and not passing the buck.

Videos.name: Adaptability
Videos.description: This video helps you understand what adaptability means and has some tips to help you develop this skill.

Videos.name: Authority
Videos.description: We’re influenced by people in authority all our lives, and there’s some authority we like and some we don’t.  Authoritative communicators are influencers, not brow-beaters...

Videos.name: Balance
Videos.description: The best managers stay in control of themselves and their emotions; they stay balanced...

Videos.name: Cognisance
Videos.description: Cognisance is a combination of how a person feels, and understanding the effect they have on those around them...

Videos.name: Delegation
Videos.description: At the heart of genuine delegation is the word trust...

Videos.name: Insight
Videos.description: You have to understand your team members in order to manage them well...

Videos.name: Motivation
Videos.description: Successful leaders are successful motivators and the key is your workplace attitude...

Videos.name: Networking
Videos.description: Networking is the ability to form and sustain close working relationships with everyone in your team...

Videos.name: Objectivity
Videos.description: We are unbiased and objective when we are not influenced by personalfeelings, interpretations and prejudices.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: Building your Personal Brand is a lifelong pursuit.  But this final video reminds us there are some simple ways that you can get started.

Courses.intro_description: We all have a Personal Brand.  We don't all know what it is or how to create that strong, lasting impression on others.  The videos on this course will help you to understand, develop and live your authentic brand.
Courses.name: Personal Brand
Courses.description: Personal brand is what people say about you when you’re not in the room or online. Make sure what they say is good.

Headings.text: We all need to develop relationships
Benefit from a happier working life
How to create the right impression
To be perceived well and create impact
People will want you in their network
You, being able to network in any situation
You, building a great business network

Videos.name: Personal Brand
Videos.description: Personal Brand is the powerful, clear, positive message that anyone thinks of when they think about you. It is what other people say about you when you are not in the room...

Videos.name: Listening
Videos.description: When meeting new people, most people are so concerned with what they are going to say next, or waiting for their turn to speak, they often miss vital pieces of information, or are simply not present with the new person...

Videos.name: Why and How
Videos.description: One of life's most impressive skills is the ability to remember names and details...

Videos.name: Techniques
Videos.description: There are many techniques to enhance memory. Here are some specific ones for helping to remember names...

Videos.name: Foreign Names
Videos.description: In a multi-cultural world, foreign names may be particularly hard to recall.  Here are some ideas on how to approach this...

Videos.name: Preparation
Videos.description: Preparation is really important when networking in any situation.  Here are some ideas to help you prepare...

Videos.name: Breaking the Ice
Videos.description: In this video you’ll see how to get beyond mundane conversation-starters likethe weather and transportation…

Videos.name: Thinking Style
Videos.description: When thinking about networking in any situation, a good way to approach it is to think about how you can create value for someone else...

Videos.name: Use Open Questions
Videos.description: Open questions are a brilliant way to open up a good conversation...

Videos.name: Disclosure
Videos.description: Disclosure is when you share something personal about yourself...

Videos.name: Using Compliments
Videos.description: Paying people compliments can work really well, provided it's done properly...

Videos.name: Transitioning
Videos.description: This video explores how to seamlessly shift the topic of a conversation tosomething of importance…

Videos.name: Be Honest
Videos.description: Exiting conversations can be a real challenge and there are some really bad methods in use out there.  Here's how to do it gracefully...

Videos.name: Park and Ride
Videos.description: Sometimes you can use other people to exit conversations.  Introduce someone to the person you're talking to, or bring them over to meet someone on their own...

Videos.name: Follow Up
Videos.description: Great progress can be made when meeting people, but keeping in touch with your network is also really important...

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: In this final video we help you to get started in building and maintaining your network with some simple actions.

Courses.intro_description: Networking is necessary in today's business world.  It's about making yourself known in the right way, for the right reasons and in the right places.  But to some people it can feel difficult, unnatural and even a little scary.  The fact is, Networking is very important to your career and during this course we'll show you how to develop a strategy towards it and how to navigate a networking event and make it work for you.
Courses.name: Networking Skills
Courses.description: Open up a world of opportunities and relationships with great networking skills.
Courses.strapline: Open doors and keep them open..

Headings.text: Influencing is a key workplace skill
Influence will make your job easier
To create excellent rapport to get results
You get more of what you want...

Videos.name: What is Influencing?
Videos.description: A great definition of Influencing is: To impel a person to some action, whilst keeping the relationship intact.  This course is about how to set about doing that...

Videos.name: Build Rapport
Videos.description: Rapport is the ability to enter someone else’s world, to make them feel like you understand them, and have a strong common bond...

Videos.name: Reflect Their Needs
Videos.description: Reflecting is about being alert to what people are saying and how people are saying it.  This video looks at the various ways of achieving it...

Videos.name: Work for a Decision
Videos.description: This video looks at various techniques that can be used to influence people towards an outcome you both want...

Videos.name: Outcome Thinking
Videos.description: We are all 100 percent responsible for the outcomes in our lives.   One way to get the outcomes we want is to think about the ways in which we react to events...

Videos.name: Know Your Outcome
Videos.description: This video focusses on distinguishing between the things we can control in our lives and the things over which we have no control...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: When trying to influence others, the way in which we communicate will have a marked effect on our ultimate success or failure, as this Video series demonstrates...

Videos.name: Push
Videos.description: The Push approach is an autocratic one.  This video looks at when it's appropriate,  and the risks associated with using it...

Videos.name: Pull
Videos.description: The Pull approach is collaborative.  This video looks at when it's appropriate,  and the risks associated with using it...

Videos.name: Logical
Videos.description: The Logical approach uses clear, unassailable arguments, supported by proof.  This video looks at when it's appropriate,  and the risks associated with using it...

Videos.name: Emotional
Videos.description: The Emotional approach involves use of the leader's natural charm, charisma and enthusiasm...

Videos.name: Assertive
Videos.description: The Assertive approach asks directly, clearly and confidently for what is or isn't wanted...

Videos.name: Passive
Videos.description: The Passive approach is when the day is won by being submissive and not overly influencing...

Videos.name: Sales
Videos.description: The Sales approach uses good old-fashioned salesmanship and this video examines the pros and cons...

Videos.name: Bargaining
Videos.description: The Bargaining approach trades concessions in order to reach a mutually acceptable conclusion.  This video examines the pros and cons...

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: Here are some easy and practical things you can do to actively improve your influencing skills.

Courses.intro_description: A simple definition of Influencing is to impel a person to some action, whilst keeping the relationship intact.  So effective influencing is a key skill.  It's needed to lead properly, to manage properly, to sell properly and to play a full part in a team.  Top performers need to be able to influence a wide range of people and to adopt the best style of influence that suits the specific circumstances.
Courses.name: Influencing Skills
Courses.description: Get the outcome you want whilst keeping the relationship intact.

Headings.text: Too many tasks means too little time
Life is stressful but it can be managed
You need to meet corporate standards
Rational strategies to help you manage
To deal effectively with stress & pressure
You, being able to handle far more stress
Strategies to use when stress strikes
You, ceasing to feel like a victim

Videos.name: Mindset
Videos.description: Having a positive and realistic mindset is essential if you want to maintain peak performance.

Videos.name: Breathing Smoothly
Videos.description: Under pressure our breathing usually changes and becomes slower or more rapid.  This change can affect the way we think, feel and act...

Videos.name: Yerkes Dodson
Videos.description: Research shows that performance increases with increased mental or physiological arousal.  This means you need to bring yourself up to the right level of mental and physical arousal in order to perform well at work...

Videos.name: Planning Fun Events
Videos.description: Life is more fun with something to look forward to so part of a healthy work life balance should be an active pursuit of interests outside of work...

Videos.name: Visualisation
Videos.description: Visualisation is a powerful tool and visualising success actually helps to make that success a reality...

Videos.name: Sleeping Right
Videos.description: Although the purpose of sleep is still being researched, we know it has a huge impact on our energy, mood and outlook.  Here's a checklist of things to use to help get the quality of sleep you need...

Videos.name: Relaxing Deliberately
Videos.description: The important word in the title of this video is 'deliberately'.  In an ever more stimulating environment we need to be conscious of our actions and take proper steps to create a relaxing environment...

Videos.name: Doing Practical Activities
Videos.description: Doing practical activities can really help to free the mind and that can result in a fresh perspective once back at work...

Videos.name: Exercising More
Videos.description: Exercise has multiple health benefits - both physically and mentally...

Videos.name: Eating Well
Videos.description: Eating well feeds the mind and the body...

Videos.name: Thoughts
Videos.description: Thoughts are key to our experience of life, and when something happens, we almost immediately have a cognitive reaction to it....

Videos.name: Feelings
Videos.description: In any situation, thoughts inevitably lead to feelings, and sometimes those feelings can be negative and destructive...

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: To be in control in any situation it’s important to have many choices available and to have the ability to act freely on those choices...

Videos.name: Reframing
Videos.description: Reframing a situation permits a mental change to the way certain things are viewed and can produce an outlook that is more supportive and manageable...

Videos.name: Building Your Resources
Videos.description: This exercise is a wonderful way to remind yourself of the resources available to you when resilience is required...

Videos.name: Think Like a Scientist
Videos.description: The best scientists have a stringent ethical code for approaching any new area of investigation.  They test why certain things are true and real – they look for evidence.  So can you...

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: The strategies for Managing Workplace Pressure are fairly simple and straightforward, but that doesn't mean that they're easy to implement.

Courses.intro_description: We often thrive under pressure, until we feel the demands are too great.  Deadlines start to slip, colleagues seem less cooperative and our projects appear unattainable.  We might not be able to control the workflow, but with the right techniques we can control the pressure, and indeed, turn it to our advantage.
Courses.name: Managing Workplace Pressure
Courses.description: Avoid burn out by learning how to cope with workplace pressure.

Headings.text: We all have to pitch - mainly ourselves
But you need to be seen as credible
Skilful pitching is a learned process
Any pitch has to be locked to its outcome
What to do before, during and after
How to create the perfect pitch
Making sure they get your message
You walk into meetings with confidence
Your pitches will run on a track
Your audience will be inclined to 'buy in'
The results, visible on the bottom line

Videos.name: Preparation
Videos.description: Preparation is the key to a perfect pitch. Here's a checklist that explains the things you should be thinking about...

Videos.name: Visual Aids
Videos.description: Early in any pitch preparation a decision must be taken over whether slides or a pitch book will be used. There are a number of benefits to using something the audience can see, and some caveats...

Videos.name: Practice
Videos.description: Doing something a second time is always easier and a third time easier still.  Despite knowing this, people rarely practice enough, which is a mistake...

Videos.name: On the Day
Videos.description: Here's a checklist of things to do on the day of the pitch...

Videos.name: Asking Questions and Listening
Videos.description: The worst pitches are when one person speaks and the audience merely listen. The best are when a conversation takes place with all those in the room...

Videos.name: Physical Choices
Videos.description: The way we look can project many different messages to our audience.  Here are some tips to ensure your physicality is right...

Videos.name: Vocal Choices
Videos.description: When making a pitch, the vocal objective is to be both clear and interesting...

Videos.name: Closing
Videos.description: It’s easy and logical to close a pitch when the end has been reached, but look for signals from the audience. If the audience is no longer listening, then continuing may do more harm than good...

Videos.name: Notes
Videos.description: Notes should be taken during the pitch, but probably not by you.  So have someone else there whose job it is to take notes...

Videos.name: The Post Mortem
Videos.description: Post-pitch analysis is an important part of the pitching process and both positive and negatives aspects should be reviewed, to better inform future pitches.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: This video contains some day-to-day, effective ways you can develop your Pitching skills.

Courses.intro_description: All of use have to pitch something at some time in our lives.  We know all about the thing, idea, service or person we have to sell.  We've prepared our patter and know it by heart .  Where so many of us fall down is in the way we deliver the message face to face.  That's where the videos from this course will help.
Courses.name: Pitch Clinic
Courses.description: Deliver a winning pitch every time. Learn to pitch with confidence, clarity and poise. Most importantly, get the results you want.

Headings.text: You need  to stand up for your rights
Be able to say 'no' with dignity
And assert yourself like an adult

Videos.name: Know Your Triggers
Videos.description: The ability to be truly assertive begins with knowing what provokes illogical behaviours in your work and personal life - these are known as triggers...

Videos.name: What It Looks Like In You
Videos.description: Being assertive isn’t who a person is, but what they do...

Videos.name: Building Trust
Videos.description: When a presenter knows their audience, they have a better chance of speaking to its needs.  This creates an environment of trust to more successfully assert your ideas, and benefit from theirs...

Videos.name: Outcome Thinking
Videos.description: When faced with high pressure, overwhelming situations, and enormous challenges, it can be easy to slide from assertive behaviour into aggressive or passive aggressive behaviour...

Videos.name: Being Present
Videos.description: People see the world from their own unique point of view.  That’s why it’s important never to assume the elements of your communication are automatically clear to all members of the audience...

Videos.name: Barriers to Communication
Videos.description: It’s not what you say but what people hear...

Videos.name: Why We Argue
Videos.description: Our brains are hooked on winning and humans have a fundamental desire to always be right. This creates problems...

Videos.name: Staying Logical
Videos.description: In order to stay logical it's important to take the time to stop and gather your thoughts...

Videos.name: Emotional Intelligence and Awareness
Videos.description: True assertiveness requires the exercise of emotional intelligence, so that all voices can be heard and respected, including yours...

Videos.name: Needs, Wants and Boundaries
Videos.description: In business it’s important to be very clear about the outcomes we're trying to achieve, however, each of us can get stuck in the trap of pushing our needs, while neglecting other points of view...

Videos.name: The Win-Win
Videos.description: When making contact with colleagues and clients, it's possible to improve your health by creating positive outcomes that allow for the obvious benefit of more Win Win Situations...

Videos.name: Crazy Maker
Videos.description: Crazy Makers are individuals who use behaviours such as anger, shaming, bullying and other negative conduct to control the actions and reactions of others...

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: This video looks at some things you can do every day to strengthen your assertive skills.

Courses.intro_description: If asked to pin assertive behaviour on a scale of 1 to 10 where aggressive lies at one end and passive at the other, many people say assertive behaviour sits in the middle.  But is that accurate?  You can find out this and more on this course.
Courses.name: Assertiveness
Courses.description: Feel confident enough to say ‘no’ and push back, without creating conflict.

Headings.text: A negotiation need not be adversarial
You need a win-win in every situation
How to acquire and improve those traits
Everybody gets what he or she want
You, being able to recognise their tactics
You negotiate from a place of power

Videos.name: Traits of a Top Negotiator
Videos.description: This video looks at the traits of top negotiators as defined by hundreds of professional negotiators interviewed for the creation of this course...

Videos.name: Negotiator's Social Skills
Videos.description: Great negotiators play well with others.  This video examines how social skills can be manifested in a negotiation...

Videos.name: Know Your Subject
Videos.description: A key to successful negotiations is being as prepared as possible about your subject.  The more knowledge you have about what you’re negotiating, the more tools you’ll have at your disposal to win...

Videos.name: Opposition
Videos.description: As part of preparing to negotiate, knowing your opposition is key.  Understanding their temperaments, predilections, and cultural perspectives will stand you in excellent stead...

Videos.name: Marketplace
Videos.description: 'Marketplace' in a negotiation means a set of trading conditions or the business environment where the negotiation is taking place and that a good negotiator needs to be familiar with...

Videos.name: Boundaries
Videos.description: A key to preparing for a negotiation is being able to define the boundaries of the negotiation and knowing the “must haves” and the things you're prepared to concede...

Videos.name: Listening
Videos.description: Listening builds rapport and a key advantage of rapport is trust...

Videos.name: Clarity
Videos.description: In a negotiation it’s vitally important to take responsibility for how we present ourselves.  This includes body language, how we sound, our content meaning and what we say...

Videos.name: Control and Emotional Intelligence
Videos.description: Understanding your emotions and knowing what might trigger them is key when it comes to dealing with feelings and keeping a negotiation productive when it gets challenging...

Videos.name: Additional Preparation Questions
Videos.description: This video contains additional questions that should be researched for answers prior to any negotiation...

Videos.name: Closing
Videos.description: The ideal end to a negotiation is when everyone is comfortable with the deal struck.  But this is also when it can get tricky...

Videos.name: Phone Negotiations
Videos.description: Face-to-face negotiations are nearly always better than phone negotiations, but sometimes they can't be avoided.  This video explains what to do when you have to negotiate over the phone...

Videos.name: Email Negotiations
Videos.description: Email negotiations should ideally be avoided, but if you do need to use email, here are some key things to stick to...

Videos.name: Surprise Surprise
Videos.description: The Surprise/Surprise is a last minute change in tactic designed to throw the other party in the negotiation...

Videos.name: Buck Passing
Videos.description: Buck passing is a tactic where a tough negotiation is avoided by the opposite party stating they can’t make the decision because some third party has to sign off on it.  This video looks at how to deal with it...

Videos.name: Good Cop/Bad Cop
Videos.description: Good Cop/Bad Cop is an oldie but a goodie as they say. Two negotiators, one nice, one aggressive.  Here's what to do...

Videos.name: Concession Trading
Videos.description: Psychologists refer to a phenomenon called “reciprocity”.  In negotiations, we call it concession trading...

Videos.name: Split Ends
Videos.description: Once a deal is done “in principle”, it’s tempting for people to relax, lower their guard, stop paying attention and assume it’s a straight path to signing a final document.  But is it?...

Videos.name: The Blitz
Videos.description: The Blitz is when the other side use time as a way of rushing to close a negotiation.  This video explores how to deal with it…

Videos.name: More Tactics
Videos.description: This video contains two final, but useful points about tactics…

Videos.name: A Strategy for Success
Videos.description: This video is full of tips to help you become a successful negotiator...

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: Start strengthening your negotiation skills by doing something consciously every day.

Courses.intro_description: Sometimes, negotiation in business has to be adversarial, but that's not the way to negotiate really successfully or to build long-term relationships.  Successful negotiation is collaborative and leaves people feeling good about themselves, each other and what they've achieved together.
Courses.name: Negotiation Skills
Courses.description: Get the outcome you want in an interview, meeting or crucial interaction.

Headings.text: Learn to use your voice effectively

Videos.name: Audience Profile
Videos.description: To be a great presenter you have to tailor the content to suit the audience you’ll be delivering to.  Remember: It’s less about what you want to say and more about what your audience needs to know...

Videos.name: Structure
Videos.description: When crafting a presentation, it’s crucial to have a clear and concise structure to your message so the audience can understand what you’re saying and what they’re being asked to do...

Videos.name: Formula for Great Presenters
Videos.description: Most people believe great presenters are simply born that way.  The truth is most great presenters started out by being ineffective...

Videos.name: Outcome Thinking
Videos.description: Even great presenters have to face pressures, awkward situations, and sometimes seemingly overwhelming challenges.  So what separates effective presenters from ineffective presenters?...

Videos.name: Sensory Language and Story-Telling
Videos.description: Sensory language encourages the audience to think in terms of taste, smell, touch, sound, and sight.  It's much more three-dimensional way than simple descriptive or declarative language...

Videos.name: You're In Charge!
Videos.description: Great presenters know they’re in charge of nearly every element of the presentation...

Videos.name: Congruence
Videos.description: When delivering a speech, it’s important that all the elements of the presentation, the content, vocal and physical delivery, are all congruent...

Videos.name: Q and A
Videos.description: Advanced presenters understand that Q&A, or the question and answer period that follow an address, is just as important as the presentation itself...

Videos.name: Conclusion Call to Action
Videos.description: The way you end a presentation is just as important as the way you begin.  In fact, many great speeches end precisely where they started...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: Advanced Speakers know the real work begins after the speech has ended...

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: Here's a reminder of what you need to do to give a really impressive presentation.  The key to presentation skills is commitment, and its really helpful to break your presentation into sections.  In this video, Tim explains.

Courses.intro_description: If you're looking at this topic then presenting is probably an integral part of your job, or it's going to be at some point.  Having a strong command of your presenting style, being able to flex it to the needs of any audience, and being able to think on your feet is what this is all about.
Courses.name: Advanced Presentation Skills
Courses.description: Become an expert at presenting to and engaging with an audience of any size.

You want to feel in control of yourself…
And knowledge leads to better outcomes
What you can do to improve outcomes

You, behaving like a leader, not a victim
You, feeling happier…and so do they!

Videos.name: Acknowledging Emotions
Videos.description: Dealing with feelings in the workplace can be complicated and striking the right balance is what this video is about...

Videos.name: Navigating Emotional Intelligence Through Self Awareness
Videos.description: Tools that have proven to be effective when managing our emotions in preparation for a difficult discussion, are self-awareness and the powerful question...

Videos.name: Managing Emotions and Emotional Intelligence
Videos.description: In order to manage our emotions, we first need to acknowledge that they exist...

Videos.name: Checklist
Videos.description: Here’s a check list to use to prepare you for executing a difficult conversation effectively...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: These videos about executing difficult conversations, offer tools, tips and techniques for effective management of this sometimes tricky task...

Videos.name: Beginnings
Videos.description: When beginning a difficult conversation, timing really is critical...

Videos.name: Intention and Language
Videos.description: Difficult conversations are essentially about solving problems.  It's useful to remember to encourage the other person to seek solutions...

Videos.name: Demonstrate Listening
Videos.description: Acknowledging you've heard the other person is key to building trust and ensures the other person knows you understand their position...

Videos.name: Reading Body Language
Videos.description: During a difficult conversation, watch for clues in the person's body language to understand how they’re experiencing it...

Videos.name: Communicating Effective Body Language
Videos.description: When having a difficult conversation it’s equally important to manage your own body language in order to help keep the discussion productive...

Videos.name: Assertive and Aggressive Communication
Videos.description: Always work towards defusing conflict through assertive communication.  Stand up for your point of view, whilst respecting the rights and beliefs of the other person....

Videos.name: “I” Language and the Power of “And”
Videos.description: A very affective tool when having a difficult conversation is framing feedback in “I” language, rather than “you” language...

Videos.name: Closing
Videos.description: In concluding a difficult conversation, make sure the behavioural change is clear, and restate who’s going to do what, and by when...

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: When having a difficult conversation, if we get too logical too quickly, we run the risk of shutting people down.

Courses.intro_description: There comes a point in every professional career when we have to have Difficult Conversations.  Few people relish them, but they don't have to be painful if a few simple skills are applied.
Courses.name: Having Difficult Conversations
Courses.description: Create the outcome you want in difficult circumstances.
Courses.strapline: Solve the problem, build the relationship.

Headings.text: Developing a high EQ is vital to success
It may even be more important than IQ
Better impulse control and stress tolerance
You, projecting yourself as a leader
Being seen as passionate and authentic -

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: Emotional Intelligence is the ability to recognise, manage and use emotions to a positive end in verbal and non-verbal communication...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: Stress tolerance is the ability to resist or delay an impulse, drive or temptation to act and is the twin of stress tolerance...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: Whether or not we fall apart, start finger pointing or abandon hope, depends on our emotional intelligence in responding to stress...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: Self-esteem, or self-regard, is how we feel about ourselves.  In the workplace it manifests itself as being able to offer opinion and challenge others without fear of criticism...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: The way we sustain relationships is by connecting with individuals in a way they would ideally like to be communicated to...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: Flexibility is the core of emotional intelligence, the gear-shift that allows the deployment of all the other competencies, and more...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Dr. Edward de Bono characterised the various thinking styles people use to discuss and ponder ideas, both individually and in meetings.  He called them the 'Six Thinking Hats'....

Videos.name: White Hat
Videos.description: White is the hat of pure facts and data, in essence a reporter’s hat...

Videos.name: Yellow Hat
Videos.description: The Yellow hat is focused on realistic positive thinking and in essence is the optimist’s hat...

Videos.name: Blue Hat
Videos.description: The Blue Hat is the control or procedure hat that typically  sets the focus and the agenda...

Videos.name: Black Hat
Videos.description: The Black hat is focused on logical negative thinking and is cautious, conservative and judgmental...

Videos.name: Red Hat
Videos.description: Red is the hat of pure feelings and emotions that allows for the free expression of enthusiasm, passion, irrational fears and intuition...

Videos.name: Green Hat
Videos.description: Green hat thinking is all about generating new ideas with fresh possibilities and seeks creativity and alternatives...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: Assertiveness is about expressing one’s beliefs and thoughts clearly, unapologetically, and through logic.  It's about communicating in an adult and direct way...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: A brief introduction to the 7 leadership competencies - authenticity, collaboration, motivating, passion, relatablity, sharing values, and transparency...

Videos.name: Transparency
Videos.description: Transparency is the ability to avoid a hidden agenda and speak genuinely, openly and in a straightforward manner...

Videos.name: Passion
Videos.description: Passion is the ability to both feel and express passion about one's profession, job, industry and life in general, and it's key to motivating others...

Videos.name: Relatability
Videos.description: Being relatable means communicating our thoughts, feelings and insights with crystal clarity and simplicity in a way that others can relate to...

Videos.name: Authenticity
Videos.description: People wrongly confuse authenticity with habit.  In order for communication to become authentic, you need to form new habits that are closer to your own personality...

Videos.name: Sharing Values
Videos.description: The ability to define and communicate our values is key to building deep relationships...

Videos.name: Collaboration
Videos.description: Collaboration is the ability to create an environment of trust in order to draw out honesty and productivity from a team...

Videos.name: Motivating
Videos.description: Motivating is defined as the process that guides and maintains goal-oriented behaviours. It's what causes us to act...

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: If you can commit to Personal Impact in small ways every day, you'll see that it can lead to big changes in the long term.  So here are some simple actions that you can take in your daily work life to help you have more impact.

Courses.intro_description: Your success as a communicator is all about the effect you have on others.  But at an advanced level, it's also about understanding the emotions, personality and thinking styles of other people too.
Courses.name: Advanced Personal Impact
Courses.description: Dramatically enhance your interactions with colleagues and clients.

Headings.text: How other cultures really see things
Learn to get your messages across
To listen, to empathise, to be flexible
To be perceived as an informed leader
To choose the right medium every time
Having the knowledge & insight to create -

Videos.name: Self-Awareness
Videos.description: Becoming self-aware is an important part of successful communication.  This video explains what you need to become aware of to help you to communicate most effectively.

Videos.name: Questions
Videos.description: This video discusses the different types of questioning methods that can be used depending on the type of answer you need.  It also has ideas to help you communicate effectively with a diverse mix of people.

Videos.name: Flexibility
Videos.description: The ability to be flexible in your communication style and behaviour will help you get the most out of your interactions...

Videos.name: Building Trust in the Team Accountability
Videos.description: Here are some tips on how to show the team you're accountable.  By being accountable you will further build their trust.

Videos.name: Building Trust in the Team Empathy
Videos.description: Being able to see things from someone else's point of view can help you understand their situation better.  It also shows you've really listened to them, thereby engendering trust.

Videos.name: Building Team Spirit at a Distance
Videos.description: Here are some tips to help you build team spirit when the team is in multiple or distant locations.

Videos.name: Impulse Control and Emotional Balance
Videos.description: The ability to control impulses and stay balanced will really help both you and the team.

Videos.name: Listening
Videos.description: Listening is one of the most important skills in the communicating toolbox. Here we discuss the various different types of listening, including the not so good ones.

Videos.name: Assertiveness
Videos.description: Here we look at four different types of behaviour - passive, assertive, aggressive and manipulative - with emphasis on the importance of assertive behaviour.

Videos.name: Choosing the Right Medium
Videos.description: There are various mediums of communication available.  Here are some tips around which medium is best to use for the different types of messages you may wish to convey.

Videos.name: Establishing Guidelines for Your Team
Videos.description: You can choose the approach you use to best influence any given situation. Here's a reminder of the different approaches and the importance of being able to use a wide range of them.

Videos.name: The Cultural Learning Cycle
Videos.description: Here we take you through the Cultural Learning Cycle: Recognising, Researching, Relating and Reflecting.

Videos.name: High vs Low Context
Videos.description: This video discusses the notion of High and Low Context forms of communicating.

Videos.name: Monochronic vs Polychronic
Videos.description: This video looks at the Monochronic and Polychronic concepts of time.

Videos.name: Hofstede’s Cultural Dimensions - 1
Videos.description: Here we examine one of Hofstede's Cultural Dimensions: The Power Distance Index and Individuality.

Videos.name: Hofstede’s Cultural Dimensions - 2
Videos.description: Here we look at three of Hofstede's Cultural Dimensions: Masculinity, Uncertainty Avoidance, and Long-term Orientation.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: We've given you a lot of information about how to communicate effectively with your virtual and global teams.  There's a lot to take in, so in this video we give you some simple tasks to practise what you've learned.

Courses.intro_description: Technology has allowed us to form virtual international teams in disparate locations.  We can have working relationships with colleagues we've never met face-to-face, who live on the other side of the world.  This presents its own challenges.
Courses.name: Communicating Cross Culturally
Courses.description: Understand how people from different cultures communicate so that you can work more effectively with them.

People will be drawn to you
Your influencing leading to visible results
The perception of you as influential
You in control, in any situation

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: This video explores the mind/body relationship and invites you to do the same via some simple, but effective exercises...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: A person's emotional state can be defined as the overall way we feel at any given moment. This state is influenced by three main things explored in the video, which also looks at ways to positively influence the emotions...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: Winners use their physiology in particular ways. Understanding how they do this can help you feel and act like a winner

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: Humans are motivated to move away from pain and towards pleasure and this translates into two distinct forms of language, both are explored in this video...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: A well formed outcome starts with what a person really desires. This video will help define what you really want...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: Knowing how to create a positive first impression is the key influencing skill explained in this video...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: The ability to subtly match and mirror another person is a useful influencing skill looked at in this film...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: This film will explain what to do to create and maintain a powerful personal presence...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: Pacing is another useful influencing skill explained in this module...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: To lead someone in your direction of thinking is another subtle skill examined here...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: To listen with empathy means being able to put yourself in another person's shoes. Here's how to do it effectively...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: This video explores the difference between 'Open' and 'Closed' questions and explains what both are and how to get the answers you need...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: A fascinating look at the mechanics of how the mind processes information, something the mind needs to do faster than ever before in today's rapidly paced world...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Much of the information we take in becomes deleted, distorted or generalised in some way to prevent us becoming overwhelmed by too much data. This video introduces a model that can help you decode information hidden in people’s communications…..

Videos.name: Fuzzy Nouns
Videos.description: Fuzzy nouns are used by people who haven’t made clear exactly what , or even who, they are talking about.

Videos.name: Vague Verbs
Videos.description: When a speaker omits important information by deleting a verb, it's useful to know how to retrieve it. This video shows you how...

Videos.name: Comparisons
Videos.description: Another form of linguistic deletion is the use of comparisons. This video explains how to retrieve the missing information...

Videos.name: Cause and Effect
Videos.description: Just because someone believes something, it doesn’t make it true. This video explains the techniques you can use to help another person to see this...

Videos.name: Mind Reading
Videos.description: People often claim to know exactly why another person has done something or even what they're thinking. This video shows you tactful ways to respond to such 'mind-reading' statements...

Videos.name: Interpretations
Videos.description: How do you deal with someone who constructs a belief out of two separate generalisations? Watch this video to find out...

Videos.name: Universals
Videos.description: A universal allows no exceptions and being able to respond appropriately when someone uses them, is another useful skill...

Videos.name: Opinions as Facts
Videos.description: We each inhabit our own individual world and people often present their perceptions as universal truths. This video shows you how to detect and deal with this language pattern...

Videos.name: Rules
Videos.description: Another form of generalisation is the belief someone develops that they have no choice but to behave in a particular way, as though obeying some unspoken rule. This video shows how to recognise and deal with such self-limiting behaviour, in yourself and others...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: The only meaning anything has is the meaning a person puts on it. Knowing how to reframe negative meanings into positive ones is another influencing skill...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: Our minds tend to divide information into either larger or smaller categories in order to process and to use it. Questions can be asked to detect which tendency a person has, and so direct and influence them. The video explores this useful skill...

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: Here are some simple actions you can take that will help you to achieve greater influence.

Courses.intro_description: This course is for anybody who has to regularly influence a range of people from clients to colleagues, from juniors to seniors.  In this course we're looking at the mechanics of how to effectively influence others and the underlying nuances involved in the process.
Courses.name: Influencing in Action
Courses.description: Learn how to get what you want from people ethically.

Chapters.name: Virtual Teams - Pros, Cons and the Role of the Manager

Videos.name: Pros, Cons and the Role of the Manager
Videos.description: This video discusses the many advantages and challenges to be faced when leading a global team.

Chapters.name: Virtual vs Face-to-Face The Extra Demands

Videos.name: Extra Demands
Videos.description: This video will help you understand how you can get the best out of communicating when you are unable to see the person or people you are talking to.

Videos.name: Being Present
Videos.description: Being 'present' on a conference call sounds like an odd concept - but it's really important to understand how this can help you, and those you're communicating with, to get the best out of this form of communication.

Videos.name: Purpose, People, Practice
Videos.description: Follow the ‘Purpose, People, Practice’ model to help stay on track when you’re preparing and delivering a message.

Videos.name: Plain Language & Verbal Economy
Videos.description: Delivering a focused, coherent, concise message that makes sense to everyone listening is crucial when communicating virtually.   Here are some tips on how to achieve this.

Videos.name: Tone, Energy, Emphasis, Clarity
Videos.description: Here we offer guidance on the best way to use your voice to make certain people really want to listen to you.

Videos.name: Before
Videos.description: Before you even set a meeting, here are some good questions to ask yourself, along with some rules to follow, to ensure the meeting will be a really effective one.

Videos.name: During
Videos.description: Here you will find useful guidelines to follow during your meeting.

Videos.name: Dealing with Disagreements
Videos.description: Disagreements arise from time to time - it's part of life.  Having a plan to deal with them will help all parties to reach a harmonious conclusion.

Videos.name: Afterwards
Videos.description: It's really important to follow up after any meeting.  Here are some tips about how to best do this most effectively.

Videos.name: Conference Call Etiquette
Videos.description: Here are some Do's and Don'ts to consider for before and during your conference calls.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: We've given you a lot of information about how to communicate effectively with your virtual and global teams.  There's a lot to take in, so in this video we give you some simple tasks to practise what you've learned.

Courses.intro_description: There's an art to virtual communication and it's what we focus on in this course.  Maintaining a powerful virtual presence is more difficult than it is for face to face communication but it's achievable with practise, using the techniques we discuss here.
Courses.name: Communicating Virtually
Courses.description: Build strong relationships with distant colleagues  and  friends. Make video calls and other virtual communication mediums work for you.

Headings.text: To get the tools to write effectively
To understand why you're even writing
The importance of the five W's
Why you need to use B.L.O.T.
Your messages get read and understood
Your work is clear, concise & compelling

Videos.name: Purpose of Business Writing
Videos.description: There are all kinds of different writing styles, but Business Writing is about getting your message across in a clear, focused and engaging way.

Videos.name: Choosing the Medium
Videos.description: At work you can call, email or instant message;  but the most effective business writers know when NOT to write.

Videos.name: Aim Introduction
Videos.description: Before you write anything, the most important question to ask yourself is what's your aim?  What is your communication trying to achieve?

Videos.name: Putting Your Aim into One Sentence
Videos.description: When you write, you're generally either asking for something or providing something.  Either way, it helps to write down your aim.

Videos.name: Aim of the Relationship
Videos.description: When composing a message it's also important to consider how you want your reader(s) to feel.

Videos.name: The Five W's
Videos.description: Once you know about the Five W's you'll soon be stating your aim more clearly.

Videos.name: BLOT Writing
Videos.description: BLOT is an acronym that highlights the key difference between Academic Writing and Business Writing.

Videos.name: SCAN
Videos.description: SCAN is an acronym explaining that when people are reading from their screens, you need to formulate your message in a certain way.

Videos.name: Top Down Writing
Videos.description: Top Down writing is about creating a logical order for your content, based on your aim.

Videos.name: The Highlighter Test
Videos.description: This shows you how to do a quick exercise that checks your writing is relevant to your audience and your aim clear.

Videos.name: Vague Phrases
Videos.description: A sure way to bury your aim is to write using vague phrases.  This film explains how to get rid of them, thus clarifying your aim and reducing your writing by 30%.

Videos.name: Audience Introduction
Videos.description: Each of us will tend to write the way we ourselves most prefer.  This film is about tailoring your message to your audience.

Videos.name: Personality Types
Videos.description: We all fall into four broad, personality types that each prefer to communicate in a certain way.

Videos.name: Drivers
Videos.description: Driver personalities tend to be very task oriented and to not need much detail to reach decisions.  This film suggests the best way to write to them.

Videos.name: Analyticals
Videos.description: Analytical personalities tend to be detail oriented and to like a lot of information to reach a decision.  This film suggests the best way to write to them.

Videos.name: Amiables
Videos.description: Amiable personality types tends to be non-confrontational and prefer a warm and friendly approach.  This film suggests the best way to write to them.

Videos.name: Expressives
Videos.description: Expressive personality types tend to be big-picture thinkers to whom personal rapport is very important.  This film suggests the best way to write to them.

Videos.name: Culture, High Context and Low Context
Videos.description: There are many unwritten rules within every culture that dictate what is considered good communication.

Videos.name: Jargon
Videos.description: Jargon may be helpful to show what you know, but you're writing to get your message across clearly, and jargon can get in the way.

Videos.name: Cliches
Videos.description: Cliches are words, phrases, and figures of speech, that through over-use have become a bit tedious.

Videos.name: Buzzwords
Videos.description: Buzzwords are similar to cliches and tend to be specific to the world of business. There's a danger cliches may confuse your audience as often they are vague.

Videos.name: Questions
Videos.description: Questions are a great way to connect with your audience and can help you to get inside the mind of your reader.

Videos.name: Approach Introduction
Videos.description: The previous section looked at defining your aim.  This section examines the kind of approach to take.

Videos.name: Effective Headings
Videos.description: Headings are the signposts within your writing that tell the reader where to find the information they need.

Videos.name: Effective Subject Lines
Videos.description: It doesn’t matter how well-written or beautifully organised your message is, if nobody bothers to open it.

Videos.name: Effective Paragraphs
Videos.description: A paragraph is essentially a block of thought.  To make them effective you want to be sure of a few things.

Videos.name: Effective Sentences
Videos.description: An effective sentence needs to be short and well constructed.

Videos.name: White Space
Videos.description: The white space around your writing represents the room you give your reader to breathe and to consider your ideas.

Videos.name: Active Verbs
Videos.description: This film explains the importance of writing in the Active Voice and how to keep your writing Active whenever possible.

Videos.name: Concise Language using Fewer Words
Videos.description: This film looks at some of the bad habits prevalent in Business Writing and explains why 'less is often more'.

Videos.name: Clear Language
Videos.description: Einstein said “If you can’t explain it to a six-year-old, you don’t understand it yourself.”  A helpful reminder why we need to keep things simple and plain.

Videos.name: Human Tone
Videos.description: Research shows that business readers prefer writing that sounds personable and human.

Videos.name: Buried Verbs
Videos.description: An explanation of the Buried Verb and why we shouldn't complicate our writing by using them.

Videos.name: Proofreading Introduction
Videos.description: There's usually no way to recall an email with an embarrassing error in it.  This video looks at the importance of checking before sending.

Videos.name: What to Look for
Videos.description: Your spellchecker will miss a surprising amount of mistakes.  This video highlights what to look out for.

Videos.name: Email Etiquette
Videos.description: Using 'reply all' isn’t the only bad habit when it comes to email.  This video investigates how to behave with email.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: We've talked about a lot of tools to get your message across crisply and cleanly and to help you to connect with your audience in a more human way.  Now it's time for you to practise.

Courses.intro_description: Business Writing is the ability to get business done through the written word.  It's never been more crucial than it is today.  Computers, the internet, email, instant messaging, texting, have allowed us to expand business across the globe and get a lot more done much faster.  But there are some real challenges.
Courses.name: Effective Business Writing
Courses.description: Learn a business writing style that gets your messages across quickly, clearly and professionally. Make sure your emails are read.

Headings.text: Your meetings need to be successful
How to make a meeting work
What to do before a meeting
What to do during your meeting

Videos.name: What Makes a Meeting Ineffective?
Videos.description: The late Harvard economist John Kenneth Gailbraith observed that 'Meetings are indispensable when you don’t want to do anything'.

Videos.name: What Makes a Meeting Effective?
Videos.description: In our previous video we considered the elements that get in the way of a successful meeting. Now, let’s take a moment to consider the things that work.

Videos.name: How to Prepare for Meetings
Videos.description: The next series of videos focus on how to prepare for meetings.

Videos.name: Know Your Outcome
Videos.description: One of the best ways to imbue your meetings with a sense of purpose is to define your outcome and, most critically, communicate that Outcome to meeting participants.

Videos.name: Decide if a Meeting is Necessary
Videos.description: This film explores the idea of 'being there' and considers the question: Is this meeting actually necessary?

Videos.name: Invite the Right People
Videos.description: Sometimes we've been forced to attend a conference call, video conference or face to face meeting but the topic had nothing to do with us, our team, or our area of expertise.

Videos.name: Set an Agenda
Videos.description: A meeting with no clear Agenda, no clear purpose or no organisation, is probably not a meeting you would like to attend!

Videos.name: Effective Agendas
Videos.description: In this video we carry out a development exercise around creating an effective agenda by comparing two different versions.

Videos.name: From the Top
Videos.description: Here are a few tips to help kick off your meeting with clarity, intention, and (most importantly) collegiality, or the human touch.

Videos.name: Personality Styles
Videos.description: The meeting has started well but how do you keep up the momentum? Here are some answers.

Videos.name: Involve Your People
Videos.description: In a meeting, sometimes participants can feel left out and disengaged unless they've been given a specific reason for being there.

Videos.name: Dealing with Disruptive People
Videos.description: Often, the key to dealing with Disruptive behaviors in a meeting is how you go about it.

Videos.name: Finish Strong
Videos.description: If a meeting ends in the right way there’s a sense of completion and satisfaction. Here are some ideas around how to achieve that.

Videos.name: Communication
Videos.description: At its root, running an effective meeting is about clearly Communicating goals and ideas to clients, colleagues and stakeholders.

Videos.name: Tone
Videos.description: Whether you’re sending out information about a meeting, or conducting the meeting itself, pay attention to your Tone; how you say something is as important as what you say.

Videos.name: Energy
Videos.description: Much can be said on the topic of Energy but in the end it boils down to three key components: Attitude, Focus and Intensity

Videos.name: Language Choices
Videos.description: How much of this can you listen to before you want to push Fast Forward?  Um, welcome. Uhhhhhh, I, um…. y’know, was, ummmm… looking at the agenda…

Videos.name: Body Language
Videos.description: Frequently our bodies are sending out messages about our state of mind or opinions without us even knowing it.

Videos.name: What about Virtual Meetings?
Videos.description: How should you conduct a virtual meeting? Do the same rules apply as in a Face to Face meeting?  If not, what’s different?

Videos.name: Video Conferences Do's and Don’ts
Videos.description: Video Conferences provide the opportunity to be both seen and heard.  Here are a few specific Dos and Don’ts to keep in mind.

Videos.name: Conference Calls Do's and Don'ts
Videos.description: On an audio conference call, how do you get your message across clearly and expressively when you can't see the other participants?

Videos.name: What Happens After the Meeting
Videos.description: When your meeting is over,  there are certain things you can do that can help to embed ideas and remind people of action items.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: In this final video, Paul poses some final questions.  When it comes running more effective meetings, what are the things you now need to stop, start or continue?

Courses.intro_description: What are the elements of an effective meeting?  How do you know when a meeting is necessary or not?  What are the pitfalls to avoid or the areas to emphasise when meeting with internal or external stakeholders?  This course is designed to help you get answers to those questions.
Courses.name: Running Effective Meetings
Courses.description: Create an energy and direction that will make your meetings succeed.
Courses.strapline: A good meeting is a short meeting.

Headings.text: You want the best for colleagues
Learn the techniques that get results
The vital skill of really listening
In helping others, you help yourself

Videos.name: Trust
Videos.description: Without Trust, any attempt to coach a colleague will be fruitless and  helping them to take the risks needed to reach their full potential will be close to impossible.

Videos.name: Potential
Videos.description: Coaching must be based on the assumption that every person has the Potential to grow and become something greater.

Videos.name: Commitment
Videos.description: A person's motivation to achieve long-term goals only stays strong when they have a firm internal Commitment to that particular outcome.

Videos.name: Execution
Videos.description: The job of the coach is to neither pull nor push his or her colleague in a predetermined direction, but instead to allow them to find their own journey.

Videos.name: Whats the Mission?  Part 1
Videos.description: Your number one goal should be to challenge your colleagues to chase their fulfillment and fully express their true selves.

Videos.name: Whats the Mission?  Part 2
Videos.description: When coaching, it's important to establish what your colleague's 'big picture' is in terms of their highest goals.

Videos.name: The Importance of Listening
Videos.description: It’s impossible to coach, mentor or lead others successfully without mastering the art of genuinely listening, which can be harder than it sounds.

Videos.name: What is Guided Discovery?
Videos.description: Guided Discovery is when a coach sets the framework or agenda, but allows the colleague to discover the answer for themselves.

Videos.name: Choosing Congruency
Videos.description: Vocal and physical congruency of what you say and do are paramount to building trust and rapport with others.

Videos.name: Mirror and Adapt
Videos.description: When people are in total rapport, they mirror each other non-verbally through something called Limbic Synchrony.

Videos.name: Tap into Your Curiosity
Videos.description: The more you actively enjoy being curious, the more natural and gratifying the coaching or mentoring experience will be for you.

Videos.name: Three Coaching Questions
Videos.description: This film focuses on three big coaching questions that the aspiring coach will find very helpful.

Videos.name: Trust Your Intuition
Videos.description: When coaching you will sometimes have hunches about a situation.  This video looks at how to handle your hunches.

Videos.name: Face up to the Facts
Videos.description: FACTS is an acronym for an alternative approach to coaching that in some circumstances may be more effective than traditional methods.

Videos.name: Feedback
Videos.description: In the FACTS model the F is about the important subject of providing your colleague with Feedback to assist them in their coaching.

Videos.name: Accountable
Videos.description: In the FACTS model, the letter A stands for Accountable in reference to holding your colleague accountable for the commitments they make.

Videos.name: Courageous
Videos.description: In the FACTS model, C stands for Courageous since the pursuit of big goals often involves courage.

Videos.name: Tension
Videos.description: In the FACTS model the T stands for Tension since the model suggests that Tension is required in coaching to achieve optimal performance.

Videos.name: System Thinking
Videos.description: In the FACTS model the S stands for System thinking, since a coach's job is to raise the colleague's awareness of the System they work in as a whole.

Videos.name: The Coaching Group
Videos.description: The more you’re able to exchange tips, thoughts and experiences with your fellow delegates, the more your entire organisation can grow and develop.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: Successful coaches or mentors bring out the very best in others.  What a tremendous gift to be able to share.  But to achieve it takes deliberate action.

Courses.intro_description: A great coach can transform the achievements of others in a surprisingly short period of time.  They can unleash hidden talents or help someone to achieve greatness.  They can bring better results and a happier culture across an entire workforce.  Find out how on this course.
Courses.name: Coaching and Mentoring
Courses.description: Develop the people around you through powerful dialogue.

Headings.text: All leaders need to be good at this
Going 'with your gut' is not enough

Videos.name: Being Disciplined and Scientific
Videos.description: The best feedback is translated into practice on a small set of critical performance indicators using terms people readily understand.

Videos.name: Active Listening
Videos.description: When giving feedback, the fatal mistake is to fail to listen as it will destroy your credibility and the employee's belief in the usefulness of feedback.

Videos.name: Identifying & Encouraging Good Behaviour
Videos.description: Positive reinforcement strengthens behavior and is a system of rewards that can simply take the shape of thoughtful, appreciative feedback.

Videos.name: Where, When, How?
Videos.description: When planning a feedback session, respecting the employee's time, space, and privacy is incredibly important.

Chapters.name: Setting Up Expectations and Avoiding Pitfalls

Videos.name: Ineffective Feedback
Videos.description: This film takes a look at six reasons why feedback can often be counterproductive.

Videos.name: BOOST and SMART
Videos.description: BOOST and SMART are both acronyms to help you to remember what's important when you're giving feedback.

Videos.name: SBI, STAR, AID
Videos.description: Discussing the effect of an employee's behaviour that you see as negative, can be challenging.  Here are two models to help

Videos.name: GROWTH
Videos.description: GROWTH is a model that asks you and your employee to share perspectives on what has already happened, and what ought to happen, going forward.

Videos.name: Word Choices
Videos.description: This video provides more ideas around the trickier aspects of providing feedback.

Videos.name: Feedback as a Guided Inquiry and Self Reflection
Videos.description: Here are some simple questions that can form a useful part of the feedback conversation.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: Start taking physical notes on the behaviours you observe in the feedback recipient.  This final video of the course is full of useful suggestions.

Courses.intro_description: Delivering effective, compelling feedback is something we all want to be good at.  Helping a colleague or someone who reports to us to improve his or her workplace performance involves a candid review of successes, challenges and failures.  It's also an opportunity to deep the level of trust and honesty in the relationship.
Courses.name: Delivering Compelling Feedback
Courses.description: Boost the confidence of others around you and help them to learn about themselves.
Courses.strapline: Great feedback leads to great improvements.

Headings.text: High EI makes high success likely
You need both IQ and EQ
The 8 behaviours of the EBW model
How to manage your stress levels

Videos.name: Introduction - What is EI?
Videos.description: Decades of research now point to emotional intelligence as the critical factor that sets star performers apart from the rest of the pack.

Videos.name: Introduction - What is the EBW Model?
Videos.description: The EBW model is a practical, work-based model of Emotional Intelligence that helps you to be better at it.

Videos.name: Introduction to Personality Styles
Videos.description: Self-knowledge is a vital piece of the Emotional Intelligence puzzle. The more we know about ourselves, the more we can identify with others.

Videos.name: The Driver
Videos.description: Drivers are just that. They get things done, and they don’t have time to waste on small talk on minutia.

Videos.name: The Amiable
Videos.description: Amiables like to be measured by their relationships, rather than their accomplishments.

Videos.name: The Analytical
Videos.description: The Analytical is all about facts, figures and analysis. They seek data, and will often create methods and systems to categorise and organise.

Videos.name: The Expressive
Videos.description: Expressives get really excited at the start of a project, but can suffer from a lack of follow-through when the initial excitement wears off.

Videos.name: Personality Styles - Conclusion
Videos.description: Did you identify yourself in one of the four personality styles? Did you recognise aspects of yourself in each one?  How about your stakeholders?

Videos.name: The 8 Behaviours Introduction
Videos.description: Here's an introduction to the EBW model. We'll be defining the 8 behaviors and giving tips about each of them in the videos to come.

Videos.name: Decisiveness
Videos.description: If you’re Decisive it shows you’re comfortable with, and eager to take on, responsibility. It shows we can trust your abilities because you do.

Videos.name: Motivation
Videos.description: Here we look at the three essential intrinsic motivators in the business setting.

Videos.name: Influencing
Videos.description: If you have a specific outcome in mind, it will help to define what you can actually influence and what you can’t.

Videos.name: Circle of Influence vs Concern
Videos.description: This film looks at the opposite of your influencers which are your Concerns, and what you can do about them.

Videos.name: Adaptability
Videos.description: The person with the most adaptable behaviour in a difficult situation can influence the outcome more effectively than someone who finds it hard to adapt.

Videos.name: Empathy
Videos.description: The ability to empathise with the people we work for and with helps drive powerful connections at work.

Videos.name: Conscientiousness
Videos.description: The ability to be more focused and present in the workplace leads us to make more emotionally intelligent decisions. But at work there are many distractions.

Videos.name: Stress Resilience - Emotional Control
Videos.description: The ability to manage workplace pressure and the emotions that go along with it is really quite logical and simple. This video takes a look.

Videos.name: Stress Resilience - Emotional Control Triggers
