Videos.description: Knowing how to define your emotional triggers can help you resist stress, and give you more emotional control.

Videos.name: Self Awareness
Videos.description: In virtually every great entrepreneur, manager, and leader there's one quality that trumps all. That quality is self-awareness.

Videos.name: Examine Your Stakeholders Introduction
Videos.description: We’ve spent time examining your own Emotional Intelligence. Now it’s time to apply that same awareness to your stakeholders.

Videos.name: Audience Profile
Videos.description: Being able to flip the lens and understand your audience is key to showing Emotional Intelligence and Empathy. Here's how…

Videos.name: Relationships
Videos.description: How effective are your working relationships?  Have you made a commitment to them?

Chapters.name: How to use EI in the workplace

Videos.name: Reaction and Choice
Videos.description: The more you understand your emotions, the more conscious you can be of the choices you make when it comes to those emotions.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: Phil Daniels a professor of psychology at Brigham Young University is credited with devising a process called Start-Stop-Keep that asks some valuable questions.

Courses.intro_description: Daniel Goleman, author of 'Emotional Intelligence' writes that, 'in a very real sense, we have two minds, one that thinks and one that feels'.  What is Emotional Intelligence or EQ?  How can you understand your emotional behaviours at work and be the best version of yourself?  How can you understand your stakeholders' EQ?  This course is designed to help you get answers to those questions.
Courses.name: Emotional Intelligence
Courses.description: Become a more effective human being by learning to manage the emotions of yourself and others.

Headings.text: You need to really listen to understand
How to listen better through questions
You, better able to solve problems

Videos.name: Effective Listening Overview
Videos.description: Effective listening is the ability to actively understand information provided by the speaker, and much more as well.

Videos.name: Empathetic Listening
Videos.description: The highest form of listening we can obtain is being able to listen with empathy.

Videos.name: Staying Focused
Videos.description: It may sound ridiculously simple, but often the reason we fail to reach an outcome is because our focus has wavered.

Videos.name: Body Language and Presence
Videos.description: When you’re mindful with your body language, you can maintain your own focus and maintain others’ focus on you.

Videos.name: Non-Verbal Messages
Videos.description: You need to be sensitive to the nonverbal message you’re sending with the shape, position, orientation and arrangement of your whole body and limbs.

Videos.name: Don’t Fake It
Videos.description: If you pretend to focus, what you’re focusing on is the pretending, not on the person you’re listening to.

Videos.name: Show Your Mood
Videos.description: Stay focused by staying open and transparent.  Rather than fake interest, show your authentic mood.

Videos.name: Breathe
Videos.description: The quickest way to re-center yourself and maintain focus is with organised, rational breathing, or what’s known as the “square breath”.

Videos.name: Repeat and Rephrase
Videos.description: Another way to stay focused is to use the technique of repeating or rephrasing what we heard the other person say, before we speak.

Videos.name: The Great Question
Videos.description: To effectively listen, we need to be willing to stop talking, draw out the other person’s point of view, and really listen to what they have to say.

Videos.name: Closed Questions
Videos.description: Closed ended questions are designed to get very specific information from the other person.

Videos.name: Open Questions
Videos.description: Open questions are designed to draw out someone's opinions, feelings, and knowledge

Videos.name: Probing and Clarifying
Videos.description: Probing and clarifying questions are designed to give us more information on a topic we’ve already been discussing.

Videos.name: Summary Questions
Videos.description: Summary questions can be a great way to honestly check that you get what the other person is telling you.

Videos.name: During Conference Calls
Videos.description: On a conference call participants can’t see you, and you can’t see them.  It can be very tempting to multi task.

Videos.name: Over the Phone
Videos.description: Over the phone, we can’t see or be seen, but listeners can hear when you loose focus.

Videos.name: Over Telepresence
Videos.description: This film looks at some challenges to overcome when it comes to listening over telepresence.

Videos.name: Face to Face
Videos.description: Here are some common sense listening tools that can be applied during face-to-face communication.

Videos.name: Face to Face - Meetings
Videos.description: The same common sense listening tools that can be applied to individual face-to-face communication, also apply to group face-to-face meetings.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: Phil Daniels a professor of psychology is credited with devising a process called Start-Stop-Keep that asks some valuable questions.

Courses.intro_description: Author Stephen Covey once said, 'most people do not listen with the intent to understand, they listen with the intent to reply'.  Consider that for a moment.  How much do you listen to understand the people around you?  How often do you recognise in the nuance of how they say things, how they're feeling or why they're acting the way they are?
Courses.name: Effective Listening
Courses.description: Listening is an action that binds all humans together and is a powerful tool for boosting relationships.

Headings.text: Learn to see failure as feedback
To bounce back rapidly from knocks
How to to use humour and optimism
About the benefit of acts of kindness
You know who to turn to
You can change your thinking patterns

Videos.name: Managing Strong Feelings and Impulses
Videos.description: Rather than letting failure deplete our resolve, what would happen if we were able to bounce back stronger and more determined to achieve our goals?

Videos.name: Seeing Failure as Feedback
Videos.description: This film takes a closer look at 'seeing failure as feedback'.

Videos.name: Utilising Optimism and Humor
Videos.description: Allowing ourselves to laugh is a powerful aid to resiliency and can help break negative thought patterns.

Videos.name: Making and Executing Attainable Plans
Videos.description: Rather than being consumed by all the things that have gone wrong, focusing on small steps and achieving them can be a powerful tool.

Videos.name: Reflecting and Strategising Overview
Videos.description: This video contains an exercise around resilience; you may want to have a pen and paper handy.

Videos.name: Positivity Ratio
Videos.description: Changing our thinking patterns can alter our emotional patterns.  And when it comes to resilience, recognising our emotional patterns is key.

Videos.name: Acts of Kindness
Videos.description: Numerous studies suggest that people who engage in acts of kindness, whether it be giving, receiving or witnessing these acts, experience increased serotonin production.

Videos.name: Relationships
Videos.description: Knowing who to turn to as we move through challenging times can be one of the most important resources we have.

Videos.name: Refining our Reactions
Videos.description: Being able to successfully leverage challenges as opportunities to grow and learn, contributes greatly to one’s resilience.

Videos.name: Mental and Physical Health
Videos.description: Another component of a strong level of resiliency is the capacity to take care of ourselves, even when things go badly.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: Phil Daniels a professor of psychology at Brigham Young University is credited with devising a process called Start-Stop-Keep that asks some valuable questions.

Courses.intro_description: Resilience is the ability to recover quickly from the difficulties that life may bring.  Or, put more simply, it's the tool that allows us to bounce back when we get knocked down.  In a perfect world, everything would go exactly as we planned in our personal and professional lives.  But as we all know, despite out best intentions and diligent preparation, sometimes things don't go our way.
Courses.name: Resilience
Courses.description: Cope better with whatever is thrown at you.

Headings.text: People with presence own the room
It’s a state of mind, not a talent
Trusting yourself will earn you trust
How to 'fake it till you make it'
You, knowing how to 'walk your talk'

Chapters.name: The Three Pillars of Executive Presence

Videos.name: The Three Pillars
Videos.description: Executive Presence is built on three pillars: Your style, your substance, and your character.

Videos.name: Style Introduction
Videos.description: Style is the 'how of your communication'. This section will talk about the simple techniques you can master to display your confidence, enthusiasm, and ease.

Videos.name: Audience is a Mirror
Videos.description: New research points to something important. We are wired to connect with, learn from, and be affected by the people around us.

Videos.name: Mind/Body Connection is a Two Way Street
Videos.description: The mind-body connection is a two-way street. Feeling self-assured leads to open body language and a confident voice.

Videos.name: Energy
Videos.description: Energy is the key to delivering your message in a way that stimulates the people around you.

Videos.name: Tone
Videos.description: We have a massive vocal range at our disposal but much of the time we use only a tiny percentage of it.

Videos.name: Economy
Videos.description: Functional MRI’s reveal that simpler language stimulates more parts of the listener’s brain than typical business waffling.

Videos.name: Breathe
Videos.description: Breath couldn’t be more important in our ability to communicate. It not only keeps us alive but is the fuel for a confident sounding voice.

Videos.name: Clarity, Articulation, Projection, Pace
Videos.description: One of the clearest signals of your presence as a leader is the vocal clarity of your message:  your projection, your pace, and your articulation.

Videos.name: Eye Contact and Body Focus
Videos.description: 'Always look them in the eye'. We associate relaxed and sustained eye contact with people who are telling the truth.

Videos.name: Body Language, Posture, Gestures, Stillness
Videos.description: According to psychologist Albert Mehrabian, 55% of the impact of your communication is based on how you look.

Videos.name: Practice and Preparation
Videos.description: We’ve all heard the saying 'practice makes perfect'. But in this case, perfection isn’t the goal. Authenticity is…

Videos.name: Character Introduction
Videos.description: Character is the foundation of your presence. It’s the sum total of you: your values, beliefs, talents, and formative experiences.

Videos.name: Authenticity
Videos.description: Authenticity is important because if we're all style, and no substance, some might say we are just an 'empty suit'.

Videos.name: Emergence Arc 1 - Victories
Videos.description: The path to leadership is rarely a straight line. It’s full of twists and turns, highs and lows, triumphs and challenges.  This is called your Emergence Arc.

Videos.name: Emergence Arc 2 - Setbacks
Videos.description: Failure should be our teacher but it can be painful to look closely at.  But reframing and communicating your failures can have unexpected benefits.

Videos.name: Values
Videos.description: When the going gets tough, we’re often fighting or fleeing and may not be in alignment with our values, as we simply try to survive the situation.

Videos.name: Integrity
Videos.description: Mahatma Gandhi famously said, “Happiness is when what you think, what you say, and what you do are all in Harmony.”

Videos.name: Substance Introduction
Videos.description: In this section we’ll talk about the importance of Storytelling, and how to Structure a story in a way that is engaging and inspiring.

Videos.name: Storytelling Structure
Videos.description: This is a very hot topic in business right now. The ability to turn your message into a compelling Story is key to influencing or inspiring others to act.

Videos.name: Storytelling Tools
Videos.description: This film looks at some tools that will help make the story even more engaging: Sensory language, Emotional language, and I-Present Language.

Videos.name: Listening
Videos.description: We have to know how to listen, when to stop talking and when to take the focus off ourselves and put it onto the other person.

Videos.name: Empathy
Videos.description: Empathy is the ability to put yourself in another person’s shoes and to identify with the feelings they may have, and adapt your message accordingly.

Videos.name: Presence in Action
Videos.description: All the skills and exercises in this course are designed to build a foundation of self-awareness, self-confidence, and authenticity.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: Thank of a leader who had a positive impact on your life, personally or professionally.  How did they make you feel and what did they do to make such an impact?

Courses.intro_description: We want our leaders to make a lasting impact on us and to have a presence that inspires us to follow them.  These videos show you how to engage people, be credible, and have that elusive quality of leaders –  gravitas.  Having impact and presence is all about developing the confidence to show who you are, the skills to communicate your values and an understanding of how others perceive you.
Courses.name: Executive Presence
Courses.description: Become the leader you always wanted to be.

Headings.text: Learn to link individual and team goals
An aligned team has to trust you
A vital leadership skill is yours

Videos.name: Alignment over Agreement 1
Videos.description: This film is about how to create a team where each individual knows the business's vision, goals, and top challenges; and is personally motivated to help the business reach its goals.

Videos.name: Alignment over Agreement 2
Videos.description: A look at how to develop trust and alignment by an examination of best and worst team practices.

Videos.name: Alignment over Agreement 3
Videos.description: A deeper look at strategies to create trust and alignment in a team.

Videos.name: Personality Styles Introduction
Videos.description: One of the keys to building a diverse and effective team is learning how to identify, understand, and use personality styles.

Videos.name: Drivers
Videos.description: In this video, we focus on the communication style known as 'The Driver'.

Videos.name: Analytical
Videos.description: In this video, we focus on the communication style known as 'The Analytical'.

Videos.name: Amiable
Videos.description: In this video, we focus on the communication style known as 'The Amiable'.

Videos.name: Expressive
Videos.description: In this video, we focus on the communication style known as 'The Expressive'.

Videos.name: Review
Videos.description: A person may relate to one style in a particular situation, while relating to another style in a different situation, or they may be a collection of all four personality styles at once!

Videos.name: Team Dynamics Introduction
Videos.description: This film is an introduction to understanding group dynamics so you will know how to organise a set of disparate people into a team, rather than a collection of individuals.

Videos.name: Forming
Videos.description: Forming' is the stage at which the team comes together and its members start to work with one another.

Videos.name: Storming
Videos.description: As its name implies 'Storming' can be a tumultuous time for the team.

Videos.name: Norming
Videos.description: During the 'Norming' stage the team integrates more, having resolved some of their differences; and team members start to bond.

Videos.name: Performing
Videos.description: At the 'Performing' stage, teams are focused on the common goal, and they can reach unprecedented levels of delivery and success.

Videos.name: BECKS Introduction
Videos.description: BECKS is the acronym for a framework you can use to assess a team.

Videos.name: Behaviour
Videos.description: More and more, Working Voices finds its clients expressing frustration with other people’s behaviour. This film makes some helpful suggestions.

Videos.name: Environment
Videos.description: We need to acknowledge the difficulties as well as the opportunities that the working Environment may present.

Videos.name: Clarity
Videos.description: A simple principle of team engagement is that good communication contributes to great performance.

Videos.name: Knowledge and Skills
Videos.description: The common purpose shared by a group of people is what defines them as a team; but you could argue that it’s knowledge that unites them.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: As we've seen, working as part of a team and leading one is complex and dynamic and needs to be addressed carefully and thoughtfully.  Here's a reminder of the things we've discussed and things you need to be doing.

Courses.intro_description: This course looks at Team Building.  It's a complex and demanding process, but the rewards it offers are immense.  As Henry Ford put it, 'coming together is a beginning, keeping together is progress and working together is a success'.  It will be a great test of leadership, whether your new to management or an old hand.  We start by defining what we mean by the word 'Team'.
Courses.name: Team Building
Courses.description: Understand team dynamics to build stronger cooperation and trust.

Headings.text: You need to do more in less time
You need to be productive & efficient
Powerful choices need to be made
Discover what is wasting your time

Videos.name: The Paradox of Time
Videos.description: Most of us are balancing our career commitments with obligations to our families, friends, communities and to our own sense of well-being.

Videos.name: Prioritising Your Time
Videos.description: How do you prioritise work when everything seems to be a number one priority?  This video helps to clarify priorities and break down action steps.

Videos.name: Owning Your Own Time
Videos.description: Studies have shown that time wasting activities fall into four major categories: interruptions, distractions, pointless stuff and daydreaming.

Videos.name: Email
Videos.description: Just because email has become such an important part of our work-life, doesn’t mean that your time should be owned by your email.

Videos.name: Meetings
Videos.description: We’ve all sat in meetings wondering why we’re there and what the point is, getting increasingly frustrated as we think about all the other more important ways we could be using our time.

Videos.name: Decluttering Your Time
Videos.description: We often end up agreeing to things that we really don’t have time for, or discover we’re not the right person for the job. This film suggests alternatives.

Videos.name: Managing Your Energy
Videos.description: This film looks at four key tools you can use that will help you to get into action.

Videos.name: Clarity of Time
Videos.description: Understanding your objectives and goals with absolute clarity is at the heart of effective time management.

Videos.name: Decision-Making Tools
Videos.description: When faced with a series of tasks, you need to decide what to do first, and in what order everything else needs to be done.

Videos.name: Actions Tools
Videos.description: This film looks at four key tools you can use to get all the to do's that are stacking up, out of your head and into action.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: Productivity guru David Allen said, 'in training and coaching thousands of professionals, I found that lack of time is not the major issue.  The real problem is a lack of clarity and definition about what a project really is, and what the associated next action steps are'.  So how should you proceed?

Courses.intro_description: Famous author, salesman and motivational speaker Zig Ziglar memorably said, 'lack of direction, not lack of time is the problem.  We all have 24 hour days'.  In today's busy and distracted world, we're under pressure to do more in less time.  Being productive and efficient is more important than ever, but it's increasingly hard to achieve.
Courses.name: Effective Time Management
Courses.description: Use the time you have to do the things you need to do without feeling overwhelmed.

Headings.text: To set you up to become a great presenter
It's taught by our professional presenters
To overcome any doubts and fears
How to prepare your posture and body
How to add clarity and tonal variation
You, being fully prepared to present
You, with any nerves planned away
You, ready to take it to the next level

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Fear of the unknown is one of our greatest anxieties, so doing some preparation on who your audience are will help you to understand how to deliver your presentation and will also reduce your nerves...

Videos.name: It's All in the Eyes
Videos.description: If you find maintaining eye contact difficult, Paul shows you a simple way to make it feel far more comfortable...

Videos.name: Think Like A Reporter
Videos.description: Great presentations are about getting your message across.  To do so you need to be prepared, and to know your audience...

Videos.name: It's All in the Eyes II
Videos.description: When presenting to an audience, our number one tool is eye contact.  This serves us too, because the more we take the attention off ourselves and onto the audience, the more effectively we will communicate with them...

Videos.name: The Audience Profile
Videos.description: A vital question to ask yourself when preparing any presentation is: what does the audience want from me?...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: Providing enough time to create and practice a presentation will be the key to your success...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: A successful presentation is one in which the audience are focused on the message.  Both delivery and slides need to complement each other...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: If the audience isn’t comfortable and the right equipment is missing, the presenter may well be distracted by the lack of preparation -  and focus will bleed away from the presentation....

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: People who appear relaxed, appear confident and we feel uncomfortable and get distracted watching nervous presenters.  Audiences actually listen more attentively to confident people...

Videos.name: Planning Away the Nerves
Videos.description: If you ever get nervous thinking about making a presentation, Julia explains how you can use those nerves to reframe your thoughts...

Videos.name: The Internal Dialogue
Videos.description: When thinking about presenting you may notice that your internal dialogue isn't always as supportive as you'd like it to be...

Videos.name: Using the Body to Relax the Mind
Videos.description: Most people think that the brain tells the body what to do.  In fact, it's the other way round...

Videos.name: Breathing Away The Nerves
Videos.description: Nerves are a natural part of presenting. Here Jennifer explains a relaxation technique to quiet the nerves and adrenaline...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: There are two areas to focus on to help you physically relax, posture and  breathing...

Videos.name: Releasing Tension
Videos.description: Here are a number of quick exercises from Paul that can be done anywhere, just before you do a presentation, to help release tension from different parts of your body...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Good posture is important to our health but why and what else does it give us?  Paul explains...

Videos.name: Energy Through Posture
Videos.description: Good posture helps us to feel more confident and is vital for maintaining energy. It's also really helpful when we're feeling tired, as Paul explains...

Videos.name: The Economy of Movement
Videos.description: Although moving around when presenting is fine, a lot of our clients move around too much, and this can make them look nervous, as Tom explains...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: First impressions count, so it's important to make a positive impact and create strong rapport in the first few seconds...

Videos.name: What Should You Wear?
Videos.description: Some excellent tips on how to dress when presenting...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Body language directly affects your relationship with the audience...

Videos.name: Hands
Videos.description: The question our trainers are often asked is, 'what do I do with my hands?' In this video you will learn a simple fix...

Videos.name: Observe and Learn
Videos.description: Clear, open body language is an essential part of communicating effectively.  Jennifer invites you to observe yourself and others to improve your own body language...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Rapport is not something you do to someone, it's something you have with someone.  Rapport is important because it breeds reciprocal behaviour and whoever you have it with will want you to succeed...

Videos.name: Tips for Building Rapport
Videos.description: Building rapport before a presentation can feel a little awkward, but it's crucial for both you, and the audience...

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: Here are some day to day actions that you can undertake to support your learning from Part 1 of this course.

Courses.intro_description: Whether you're speaking to large or small groups within your company or outside it, giving a presentation calls for confidence, poise and persuasion.  As communication technology becomes ever more sophisticated, the need to present information in different formats across multiple platforms, is becoming ever more important.
Courses.name: Foundation Presentation Skills - Part 1
Courses.description: Want people to agree to your proposals and pitches? Connect with your audience  and  learn how to present persuasively.

Headings.text: You need to be a dynamic presenter
Conquer nerves, look and sound great
Sooner or later you need to present
The skills to become an A1 presenter
How to enhance the way you sound
You being perceived as a great presenter

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Tone is an expression of your mood.  Also, interesting people tend to use a larger vocal range...

Videos.name: Smiling Really Does Help
Videos.description: Smiling will help to engage your audience and however you smile, it will improve your tone..

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Energy is the fuel of a presentation, the life-blood that keeps it going.  That's why energy and enthusiasm are so important...

Videos.name: Increasing Your Level of Energy
Videos.description: This video contains a simple, physical exercise that will increase your energy levels while presenting...

Videos.name: Energy Equals Intention
Videos.description: Speech energy is all about intention and that's important because it conveys faith in your material...

Videos.name: Finding Your Right Level of Energy
Videos.description: Paul shows you a simple exercise that shows how to increase your energy in a really natural way...

Videos.name: The Mirror Principle
Videos.description: When presenting, we get back from an audience what we give them.  Too little, and the audience will tune out; too much, and they will feel overloaded...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Skilled presenters know how to make their audience remember key information.  This video is about defining the message so the audience understands it...

Videos.name: Creating Meaning
Videos.description: Emphasis is a great way to create meaning when you're talking and this video provides a simple exercise to help with that...

Videos.name: Three Emphasis Exercises
Videos.description: Emphasis is vital for helping an audience to connect with your message.  It's about knowing what the key words are and making sure they really resonate when you speak...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Getting the pace right in a presentation has a powerful effect on you and the  audience. This module shows you various ways of achieving the correct pace while presenting.

Videos.name: The Power of the Pause
Videos.description: Presenters need to know that it's vital to speak at a manageable pace.  Here's a tip called the 'power of the pause'...

Videos.name: Read and Record
Videos.description: Pace is all about the presenter's perception of the audience, and it's always worth remembering that the audience may be a lot less familiar with the subject than the presenter...

Videos.name: The Power of the Pause II
Videos.description: Jennifer explains how pausing is a way for the audience to gently consider the message you're trying to send...

Videos.name: Read and Record II
Videos.description: Paul explains an exercise that can be used to slow you down when you're speaking...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Articulation is a physical act that requires physical practice...

Videos.name: The Pen Exercise
Videos.description: Tom will show you how making use of a pen in this exercise, can help improve your articulation...

Videos.name: Listen to Yourself
Videos.description: Jennifer demonstrates how practising with a recording device, combined with a tongue twister, can help your articulation...

Videos.name: The Facial Warm Up
Videos.description: All you need for this exercise is an imaginary sticky toffee.  Watch Julia to find out how this exercise can help prepare you to deliver a presentation...

Videos.name: Achieving Clarity
Videos.description: Paul demonstrates a couple of quick exercises that show how to practice a presentation in ways that will help to improve articulation...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Projecting the voice is not about shouting or just raising your voice and both are uncomfortable on the ear.  But you do need to learn to project your voice so it resonates...

Videos.name: The Humming Exercise
Videos.description: Projection is not just about volume but energy and resonance and here, Jennifer explains how humming will help to improve yours...

Videos.name: Doing It Right
Videos.description: No matter the size of the room, projection is about having a conversation and talking TO people, rather than AT them...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: When presenting, there are many distractions that can affect your level of focus. However, the audience needs you to be fully focussed.

Videos.name: Connecting
Videos.description: Focus is a great way to connect with people and Paul shows how really looking at them makes all the difference...

Videos.name: Keeping on Track
Videos.description: Here Sara explains how visualising key parts of your content in imaginary bubbles can help your presentation to stay on track...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Verbal economy is all about maximising the clarity of your message...

Videos.name: Eliminating Space Fillers
Videos.description: Space fillers can be difficult to remove from language and even harder to do during a live presentation. Jennifer explains a better way...

Videos.name: Eliminating Space Fillers II
Videos.description: Do you you...er...have...um, kind of some problems eliminating space-filler language?  Here Paul provides an excellent exercise, to eliminate it from what you say...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: We've all heard the saying 'practice makes perfect', well its true.  Since how you look and sound has a profound effect on the audience, a lack of practice can be obvious...

Videos.name: Control Your Nerves
Videos.description: Sara explains how to overcome that initial rush of nerves...

Videos.name: How to Practice
Videos.description: The most powerful tool to communicating effectively is practising OUT LOUD.  This has numerous benefits, as Henry explains...

Videos.name: The Practice Toolkit
Videos.description: How to keep practising the essential skills you have been learning about?  Sara suggests ways in which this can be done in your everyday life...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: More hints, tips and exercises to help develop your presentation skills...

Videos.name: Dealing with Mistakes
Videos.description: Everyone makes mistakes.  Here's great advice from Henry about what to do should one occur during your presentation...

Videos.name: How To Begin Your Presentation
Videos.description: The beginning of a presentation is vitally important, not least because that's when the audience tends to be most judgmental...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: This section will be useful if English is your second language...

Videos.name: The Second Language Presenter
Videos.description: The audience will know within 3 seconds if English is your second language, and that is good. In this video, Henry explains some tools to help you with your clarity, impact and the way people understand you...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Here are a selection of Tongue Twisters that can be used in a variety of ways. They help with articulation, pace and warming up the vocal chords prior to delivering a presentation.

Videos.name: Any noise annoys...
Videos.description: Any noise annoys an oysterBut a noisy noise annoys an oyster most.

Videos.name: Theo Thistler...
Videos.description: Theo Thistler, the thistle sifter, sifted a sieve of unsifted thistles into a sieve of sifted thistles then sifted a sieve of sifted thistles into a sieve of unsifted thistles for Theo Thistler was a thistle sifter.

Videos.name: Shut up the shutters...
Videos.description: Shut up the shutters and sit in the shop.

Videos.name: How much wood...
Videos.description: How much wood could a woodchuck chuck if a woodchuck could chuck wood.

Videos.name: A big beetle...
Videos.description: A big beetle bit a body in a big black bag.

Videos.name: Whether the weather...
Videos.description: Whether the weather be coldOr whether the weather be hotWhatever the weather, we'll weather the weather whether we like it or not.

Videos.name: Flee from fog...
Videos.description: Flee from fog to fight flu fast.

Videos.name: Three free things...
Videos.description: Three free things set three things free.

Videos.name: Amidst the mists...
Videos.description: Amidst the mists and coldest frosts,With stoutest wrists and loudest boasts,He thrusts his fists against the postsAnd still insists he sees the ghosts.

Videos.name: Unique New York...
Videos.description: Unique New York, New York Unique

Videos.name: How much ground...
Videos.description: How much ground could the groundhog grind if the groundhog could grind ground.

Videos.name: I'm a critical...
Videos.description: I'm a critical cricket critic

Videos.name: Betty Botter...
Videos.description: Betty Botter bought some butter but she said this butter's bitter. If I put it in my batter, that will make my batter bitter.  But a bit of better butter better than the bitter butter, that will make my batter better.

Videos.name: Oh what to do...
Videos.description: Oh what to do to die today at a minute till two 'til two A thing distinctly hard to say yet harder still to do For they'll beat a tattoo at twenty to two With a rattatta tattatta tattatta too And the dragon will come when he hears the drum At a minute till two 'til two today At a minute till two 'til two.

Videos.name: Many merry moments...
Videos.description: Many merry moments make Madge mischievous.

Videos.name: Baby buggy...
Videos.description: Baby buggy bumpers.

Videos.name: He threw three...
Videos.description: He threw three free throws.

Videos.name: Red lorry...
Videos.description: Red lorry, yellow lorry.  Red leather, yellow leather.

Videos.name: She sells seashells...
Videos.description: She sells sea shells by the sea shell shore.The shells that she sells are sea shore shells I'm sure.

Videos.name: Around the rugged rocks...
Videos.description: Around the rugged rocks ruthless Robert ran.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: Here are some practical actions you can take to embed your learning from part 2 of this course.

Courses.intro_description: Now that you've explored the psychology  and physicality of becoming a great presenter, let's now turn our attention to your voice.  You probably invest time in crafting the content of your presentations, the facts, the figures and ideas.  But how much time have you spent crafting the sound of your presentations?
Courses.name: Foundation Presentation Skills - Part 2
Courses.description: Shake off presenting nerves and dread. Learn how to present with confidence and wow your audience.

Headings.text: Great EQ = a more attractive persona
To project an easy, attractive manner
To get your messages across better

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Self Regard is how you feel about yourself and more specifically how confident you feel in your role...

Videos.name: Five Things You’re Good At
Videos.description: Our internal voice is not always our most objective critic or biggest fan.  Sometimes it tells us we are better than we are; more often, it tells us that we are worse...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Self awareness is about your ability to recognise and understand why certain situations, people and tasks create positive and negative emotions within us...

Videos.name: Get to Know Yourself
Videos.description: How can you make decisions on behalf of someone you don’t know very well? That’s why it’s so important to know yourself.  Sara provides an exercise to help you to achieve just that...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Independence is the ability to be self-reliant and self-directed in your thinking and actions; to be free of emotional dependency...

Videos.name: To Find Yourself, Think For Yourself
Videos.description: Independence is the ability to be self-reliant and self-directed in one’s thinking and actions...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Never underestimate the value of developing a good memory for building rapport and maintaining good relationships...

Videos.name: Memory Palaces
Videos.description: Your memory has almost infinite potential, if you know how to make it serve you...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: There's a considerable difference between hearing what someone has said and understanding what someone has said. Listening is the most powerful communication tool you have at your disposal...

Videos.name: Developing Empathic Listening
Videos.description: By far the most important skill within communication is listening, and the gold standard of listening is Empathic Listening...

Videos.name: Listening and NOT Listening
Videos.description: Ever had the experience when you simply wanted to be listened to, but the other person was too keen to get involved but didn't really want to listen?...

Videos.name: The Five Types of Listening
Videos.description: There are degrees in the quality of how we listen.  Our investment in listening (or lack thereof) usually comes across to our audience and to everyone else in the room, so it’s worth being conscious of how well we tend to listen...

Videos.name: The Story of Non-Listening
Videos.description: We listen to take in information, to learn more about what is going on around us and to help us improve the quality of the relationships with those we work alongside, lead or manage.  But we do have to listen...

Videos.name: What Are We Really Listening To?
Videos.description: The trouble is that we don’t ‘not listen’ because we are mean people. It's because, like everyone else on the planet, this internal dialogue is going on in our heads....

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Empathy is the ability to be attentive to and to understand the feelings of others; or put another way, to emotionally read people and respond appropriately...

Videos.name: Behaving Like An Empathetic
Videos.description: Ever had the experience of trying to tell someone about something that you find difficult, only to be fobbed off with comments that usually preface the person starting to talk about their problems rather than yours?...

Videos.name: Why Is Someone Behaving the Way They Are?
Videos.description: For us to have any hope of connection and understanding of someone in business we must value their position and take the time to understand their needs...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Responsibility may not necessarily appear to be about emotional intelligence, but it is when it's about how you demonstrate taking responsibility...

Videos.name: Response-ability
Videos.description: The word ‘responsibility’ is made up of two words – response and ability...

Videos.name: Taking Responsibility
Videos.description: Responsibility is about “taking conspicuous responsibility for what you say - without using language that appears hesitant - or distances you from the messages you are trying to convey”...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: How good are your working relationships? With your colleagues, your boss, your clients?...

Videos.name: Developing Relationships
Videos.description: Good relationships allow you to trust, relax, enjoy and enhance your work, everyday. So how much time and effort do you spend working on and building yours?...

Videos.name: 5 Steps to Building a New Relationship
Videos.description: Is there someone new at work you’re finding hard to get to know?  Here are some things you can do to help…

Videos.name: Who Have You Got?
Videos.description: We often underestimate the importance of relationships in furthering our careers and in helping the working day run smoothly...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Assertiveness is something many people find difficult to achieve. Often it's confused with inappropriately direct or aggressive behaviour. That’s where people go wrong...

Videos.name: Definition of Assertiveness
Videos.description: 'Assertiveness is the capacity to state your needs clearly to the rest of the world and pardon the rest of the World for not being psychic if you haven’t been able to state those needs clearly!”...

Videos.name: Using 'I' Statements and Plain Language
Videos.description: Assertive behaviour, language and actions are about having the confidence to commit to your thoughts, opinions and relationships with other people...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Reality testing is the ability to assess the difference between what you think is happening – the subjective – and what is really happening – the objective...

Videos.name: Observing What IS Without Opinion
Videos.description: This is a competency that seems almost too simple to mention.  It’s about knowing the difference between what we think and believe and what is actually, factually true...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: In relation to emotional intelligence, flexibility is all about how you adjust your thoughts and behaviours in the face of change...

Videos.name: Committing to "Yes"
Videos.description: We have noticed that in interactions, the person with the most flexible behaviour will control the outcome...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Holistic thinking is not about seeing the bigger picture, but about seeing the whole picture...

Videos.name: Do You Have An Eye On The Wider Picture?
Videos.description: To be effective as a leader, you need to have broad methods of thinking...

Videos.name: Getting Your Lamps Up
Videos.description: Holistic thinking in an emotionally intelligent universe is about the ability to be adaptable and to be able to keep in mind the bigger picture view of exactly how you impact the world...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Pressure, stress and the need to get things done yesterday are common concerns.  It’s easy to see things that way, and to become overwhelmed...

Videos.name: Don't Be a Boiling Frog
Videos.description: You’d think we’d see the signs of stress getting on top of us.  Trouble is, we often don’t, until it's too late...

Videos.name: The Effect of Negative Self Talk
Videos.description: A great deal of stress comes from within us. Stress could be defined by the feeling of not having the resources needed, in the moment, to deal with the situation in front of you...

Videos.name: The Square Breath
Videos.description: One of the trickier things to consider about emotional intelligence is stress tolerance. Many people mistake it to mean “I don’t feel stress”. That’s just not so...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Impulse Control can be described as the ability to defer instant gratification; to avoid the ‘quick fix’ of reacting emotionally...

Videos.name: Changing Your Mindset
Videos.description: Many of us spend our working lives going from one meeting to the next; one call to the next.  It would be lovely to prepare, but so many of our clients feel they simply don’t have time.  So what can we do?...

Videos.name: Re-learning Your Instincts
Videos.description: Have you ever had one of those moments whilst recalling events in a day when you freeze and think, “I can’t believe I said that, I can’t believe I did that; that was so stupid!”?...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Optimism is an attitude.  Mixed with a healthy dose of realism it can keep you motivated when your work life becomes challenging...

Videos.name: Radiators or Drains
Videos.description: This film illustrates the effect an optimistic or pessimistic attitude can have on other people...

Videos.name: The "Imagine If..." Journal
Videos.description: Optimism is at the top of our pyramid of interpersonal competencies for a reason...

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: Here are some day to day actions you can take to support your learning from Part 1 of this course.

Courses.intro_description: What is Personal Impact?  Why can some people walk into a room and immediately build rapport and positive vibes with those around them?  Justified self-belief, possessing an easy manner with other people, being listened to, being taken seriously.  Confidence is at the heart of it all, and this two part course shows you how to acquire these, and other essential Personal Impact techniques.
Courses.name: Personal Impact - Part 1
Courses.description: Discover the fifteen key competencies for an emotionally intelligent life and learn how to apply them in your dealings with others.

Headings.text: To be confident with peers & clients
To develop a much higher EQ
The mechanics of making an impact
To look and sound like a leader
You knowing how to 'walk your talk'
You having the look of a leader

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: Congruence occurs when what we’re thinking, what we’re saying and how we’re moving, all agree...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: So much about how we feel is communicated through our facial features. Our face is therefore a great tool for engaging and building rapport...

Videos.name: Eye contact
Videos.description: How do we establish trust? Speak from passion and authenticity? Create lasting connection to others? Eye Contact is an extraordinarily powerful tool to create all of the above and more...

Videos.name: How To Use It
Videos.description: So many of us think we’re being ‘neutral’, when in fact we’re anything of the sort...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: Often called the barometer of our emotions, hands are enormously important when we speak.  As they lie closer to our brain than our legs, they’re used most frequently by us to register our mood and to convey our intention...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Arms can indicate our level of comfort. For example, a well-known phrase is to welcome someone with open arms...

Videos.name: Gestures
Videos.description: Gestures are a great way to up your personal impact...

Videos.name: Hand Gestures
Videos.description: Gesturing helps to emphasise and animate the words when you're talking.  It is a natural way to express what's being said...

Videos.name: Handshakes
Videos.description: The first thing we do when we meet someone for the first time is shake their hand.  This has a huge impact on the first impression we create...

Videos.name: What Your Arms Are Telling Other People
Videos.description: When thinking about the impact you make, it’s a good idea to be aware that most people are experts at reading and understanding body language...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: We can inadvertently create barriers with our legs, so be mindful when crossing them.  Too closed or at the wrong angle can seem as though we’re anxious or emotional; too open and they could display arrogance or disengagement...

Videos.name: Standing
Videos.description: Sitting legs convey as much as standing legs.  Especially hidden beneath a desk when they can convey a lot more truth than when exposed to view...

Videos.name: Sitting
Videos.description: This video looks at what the legs can convey when someone is sitting.

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: The distance we are from the subject of our communication will impact our relationship with them.  Too far and we appear distant and uninterested, too close and we promote discomfort and can appear threatening...

Videos.name: Cultural Differences
Videos.description: The distance you stand or sit away from someone is driven to a large extent by the culture you were bought up in...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Being aware of the impact your language choices can have will make you a better communicator....

Videos.name: Beware of Qualifiers
Videos.description: Qualifiers have a clear grammatical function: either to make another word stronger (very, really, uniquely) or to tone it down (fairly, quite, sort of)...

Videos.name: How to Avoid Saying Um and Er
Videos.description: This simple exercise is for those of you whose favourite space filler is ‘um’ or ‘er’...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: People with great impact use a wider vocal range when communicating...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: Energy is the fuel of good communication and conversation is about an exchange of energy...

Videos.name: Matching
Videos.description: People have natural levels of energy, where they feel comfortable.  This is about making sure yours matches theirs...

Videos.name: Overview
Videos.description: The emphasis you use will dictate how well your words are remembered and interpreted...

Videos.name: Introduction
Videos.description: So much of how we want to be perceived comes from the clarity of our speech...

Videos.name: Commit To The Words You Use Everyday
Videos.description: There are some words and phrases we use every day - but remember, not everyone will be familiar with them...

Videos.name: Speaking with Precision
Videos.description: Many people complain that everyone speaks in another language when at work...

Courses.intro_description: We hope you enjoyed Part 1 and exploring your own emotional intelligence. Now that you have a foundation for success in place, we're going to look at the mechanics of delivering great impact. Namely your speech, the sound of your voice and body language.
Courses.name: Personal Impact - Part 2
Courses.description: Learn how to use your voice, body language and emotions to increase your charisma and impact on others.

Headings.text: Presentations are a fact of life in business
We create slide decks for everything
Make your messages shine & stand out
How an audience thinks and memorises
How to create slides they will remember
How to discover and state your aim
How to tap into their emotions
The ability to influence your audience
Knowing what to do and what not to do
The skills to appeal to different personalities

Videos.name: Knowing How the Brain Works
Videos.description: In order to best convey our ideas to our audience, we have to take a moment to understand how they think. Especially how their brains work... indeed how all our brains work.  Specifically, we need to understand how people process information and remember it long-term.

Videos.name: Introduction to Knowing Your Aim
Videos.description: This course will help you avoid the dreaded “death by Powerpoint”. By practicing the Triple-A method of creating your slides, you’ll be able to deliver messages that are clear, interesting and memorable.

Videos.name: Stating Your Aim
Videos.description: Before you write anything ask yourself: what am I trying to do? And write down in the answer in a sentence, including an active verb. “I need to persuade my manager to adopt this new process.”

Videos.name: Deciding How You Want Them to Feel
Videos.description: When you’re thinking about why you’re presenting, you also need to think about how you might want your audience to feel about your message.

Videos.name: Putting Your Bottom Line On Top
Videos.description: Bottom Line on Top is about stating your Aim at the beginning of your presentation. AND at the top of each slide. (We’ll talk more about effective Headlines in another video.)

Videos.name: Introduction to Knowing Your Audience
Videos.description: No two people are alike. So it follows that no two audiences will be alike. So you need to take a moment to consider who you’re presenting to, before creating your slide decks.

Videos.name: Creating an Audience Profile
Videos.description: It can be helpful to create an audience profile before you start drafting your slide deck. It will tell you what content is going to be necessary, what language you might use, what tone you might take with them, and what level of detail you might go into.

Videos.name: Doing Your Research
Videos.description: If you’re having trouble creating an audience profile, or answering the questions from the previous section, that means you have more homework to do.

Videos.name: Writing for the Four Personality Types
Videos.description: We all fall into one of 4 personality types based on how Extroverted versus Introverted and how Task-Oriented versus People Oriented we are. Our personality type will often determine how we like to communicate and what type of information we like to process.

Videos.name: Writing for Expressives
Videos.description: Expressive personality types tend to be the big idea people. You might find them in the Sales and Marketing departments. They are often big-picture thinkers, and effective team builders. Personal rapport is very important to an Expressive.

Videos.name: Writing for Analyticals
Videos.description: Analytical personalities tend to be detail-oriented. They prefer to have a lot of information so they can fully understand a situation. They also need time to process all of the data before they feel comfortable taking action or making a decision.

Videos.name: Writing for Drivers
Videos.description: Drivers tend to be very task-oriented people. They’re decisive and like to be the ones in control. They don’t need a lot of personal rapport in order to get business done. They also don’t need much detail in order make their decisions.

Videos.name: Writing for Amiables
Videos.description: The Amiable Personality Type tends to be non-confrontational. They are friendly and often a quieter presence in the office. They’ll chat about life outside the office with you, and will likely make requests in a softer, less direct style.

Videos.name: Taking the Right Approach
Videos.description: We’ve talked about knowing your Aim and your Audience. This section is about streamlining your Approach to the creation of the slides themselves. We’ll give you some tips to make drafting your presentation easier and faster.

Videos.name: Drafting What Not to Do
Videos.description: Trying to get started on a big presentation can be daunting. The two biggest obstacles we face are not knowing where to begin, and wanting to create the Perfect First Draft. This list of Do’s and Don’ts will help you get past those obstacles and on your way to creating your slide deck faster.

Videos.name: Drafting What to Do
Videos.description: Here are a few more things you can do to help you draft more efficiently, and set yourself up to succeed.

Videos.name: Creating an Outline
Videos.description: Now that you’ve collected all of your ideas about a presentation, you can now start to organise them by putting them into an outline form.

Videos.name: Slides Using the Do's and Don'ts - Part 1
Videos.description: We're going to show you some slides and ask you if you think you can tell what they mean and what the key points are...

Videos.name: Slides Using the Do's and Don'ts - Part 2
Videos.description: We looked at the Do’s in the last video. Now here are some Don’ts...

Videos.name: Deciding to Use Visuals
Videos.description: A picture is worth a thousand words. Or so the saying goes. But Is that true?

Videos.name: SHAIK-ing it Up
Videos.description: Here are some simple guidelines to help you create clear and memorable slides, and to avoid information overload.   To help you remember them, we’re using the acronym SHAIK.

Videos.name: Devising a Storyline
Videos.description: Why are we hearing so much about creating stories for business? Because our brains are wired to process information better in story form. We need a logical series of facts and events that teach us some kind of lesson.

Videos.name: Introducing Your Story
Videos.description: Humans process information very efficiently when it’s presented as a story.  No-one knows exactly why, but something about the narrative structure of a story is memorable, appealing and clear.  Here is one way to create a  story line using four steps.

Videos.name: Writing Strong Headlines
Videos.description: There are three questions we’re trying to answer for our audience as quickly as we can:  What are the facts?  What do they mean?  What do we do next?

Videos.name: Being Specific
Videos.description: It’s common for us to use vague language in slide decks.   Of course, you know what you mean, but depending on your audience, it might create confusion.

Videos.name: Using Plain Language
Videos.description: Einstein said “If you can’t explain it to a six-year-old, you don’t understand it yourself.” And while we’re not typically presenting to anyone quite that young at work, it’s really helpful to be reminded of the value of simple, plain language.

Videos.name: Making Slides Look Good
Videos.description: You’ve probably heard the principle ‘Less Is More’.  In other words, keeping things as simple and clear as possible. Uncluttered visual design is just as important as well-edited content.

Videos.name: Creating White Space
Videos.description: Having white space on your slides is crucial to making your slides readable, and your audience engaged. This video shows you how to create white space in your presentations.

Videos.name: Creating Summary Slides
Videos.description: Delegates often ask us about the ‘magic bullet’ of slide creation: how to create a single slide that will satisfy those audience members who love detail, and those who emphatically don’t.  This video shows you how to satisfy both requirements.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: This final video is a quick reminder of everything you've learned on the course. Now you know the principles for creating a clear and engaging slide deck, it’s time to PRACTISE.  Take time to define your Aim.  Think about your Audience. Create an audience profile and look at past slide decks to see how they measure up to the principles covered on this course, that are reviewed here...

Courses.intro_description: The first step to creating any slide deck is to understand why it's being created. What's the aim? What are we trying to achieve? What result do we want from our audience?  We tend to skip over this because we’re under pressure, behind on deadlines or reacting to surprises and interruptions in our work flow. So the Aim becomes “To get this project off my desk”  - a poor foundation for any presentation.
Courses.name: Slide Deck Skills
Courses.description: Wow your audience with better slide deck presentations and avoid ‘death by powerpoint’.

Headings.text: To help you break through any barriers
To be more assertive but not aggressive
To develop a strong personal brand
How to focus on your strengths
How to be your best self
Your goals aligned with your core values

Videos.name: Introduction to Conscious vs. Unconscious Communication
Videos.description: Author Steven Covey writes, “Anything less than a conscious commitment to the important, is an unconscious commitment to the unimportant.”  The only elements we have influence over in the workplace are the ways we communicate and the ways we react. That’s the good news.  The bad news is we don’t really FEEL that way...

Videos.name: Women's History
Videos.description: In the days before women had rights, how did they survive?  Research shows that one of the ways was by making sure they were liked.  Of course, likability is a crucial component to being effective at work. However if this factor is overdone, it can lead to challenges in how people perceive you.

Videos.name: Self Sabotage
Videos.description: Einstein said, “We cannot solve our problems with the same thinking we used when we created them.“  This video is about some of the ways women self-sabotage in the workplace. Do you recognise any of these elements in yourself?

Videos.name: Introduction to The Inner Critic
Videos.description: In the last video we referred to “negative self-talk.” In the next couple of videos we’re going to go a little bit more in-depth on negative self-talk and how to work with it so it empowers, rather than cripples.

Videos.name: Identifying
Videos.description: The first step to managing an Inner Critic is to identify it, which can often be tricky. Since the Inner Critic is a construct of the imagination, it can duck and hide in the recesses of the mind so it doesn’t get “found out.”

Videos.name: Getting Curious
Videos.description: Now that you’re beginning to hear your Inner Critic, it’s time to get curious about its intentions.  In her book, 'A Return to Love', Marianne Williamson famously writes, “Our deepest fear is not that we are inadequate. Our deepest fear is that we are powerful beyond measure. It is our light, not our darkness that most frightens us.”

Videos.name: Managing
Videos.description: Personal Development author Alan Cohen wrote, “If you gave your inner genius as much credence as your inner critic, you would be light years ahead of where you now stand.”  Now that you’ve identified your Inner Critic, imagine how far you could go if that voice were not running the show.

Videos.name: Positive Self-talk
Videos.description: As you become more and more adept at noticing your Inner Critic in the moment, you’ll become more adept at shutting it down, on the spot.

Videos.name: Conclusion
Videos.description: As women in leadership, there are many ways that we communicate our comfort levels with our positions, both unconsciously and consciously. By becoming acutely aware of your Inner Critic and the communication style you might tend towards, you can begin to shift your unconscious communication to make more effective conscious choices.

Videos.name: Introduction to Personal Brand
Videos.description: Simon Sinek, Author of 'Start with Why' writes, “People don't buy what you do; they buy why you do it. And what you do simply proves what you believe.' Developing a strong personal brand is what can set us apart in business. It’s the unique set of values and beliefs that people perceive in us, which is a crucial element, since perception often equals reality.

Videos.name: Core Values
Videos.description: Author Kevin Daum writes, “You don’t know your core values until you’ve articulated them clearly in writing and tested them through daily decision-making.”

Videos.name: Best Self vs. True Self
Videos.description: Amy Cuddy, author of the book 'Presence', writes, “If you’re looking to be yourself — indeed, your best and strongest self — it’s important to understand what you believe, what you value, and what your abilities are.”

Videos.name: Value Strings
Videos.description: When we talk about values, most people tend to go for the obvious ones like integrity, or honesty, which is a great starting point. But what do those words mean to you specifically, that might be different to others?

Videos.name: Deepening Your Values
Videos.description: In this video we explore more exercises to deepen your connection and exploration of your personal value system. After the explanation of each exercise, pause the video, and jot down some notes.

Videos.name: Values - Conclusion
Videos.description: Roy Disney famously said, “It’s not hard to make decisions when you know what your values are.”  Values are not morals or “shoulds”. Values are an internal barometer that tell us when we're on the right path — and when we're not.

Videos.name: Living Your Core Values
Videos.description: The great Irish playwright George Bernard Shaw said, “The single biggest problem in communication is the illusion that it has taken place.“  In order to live our core values we must be consistent with our behaviour and communication.

Videos.name: Your Big Picture Brand
Videos.description: We’ve been on a journey to find out how your Brand can help you have a more influential presence in the work place.  Living your core values or Brand everyday is vital to not only to your career, but also to your well-being.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: Phil Daniels, a psychology professor at Brigham Young University, is credited with devising a process called Start, Stop, Keep.  This technique suggests you ask yourself the following questions:  What should I Start doing?  What should I Stop doing?  What should I Keep doing?

Courses.intro_description: Eleanor Roosevelt said, “No one can make you feel inferior without your consent.”  But how has history shaped the way women communicate at work and how can women avoid self-sabotage?  This series of interactive videos is designed to help you get answers to those questions, and to use those answers to get results.
Courses.name: Womens Leadership
Courses.description: Learn the techniques that other women used on their journey to become successful leaders.

Headings.text: Critical thinking is a vital business skill
Learn where to look for flaws in statements
Get to grips with logical fallacies
Understand the dangers of confirmation bias
To identify a range of cognitive biases
To effectively challenge the status quo
A valuable ability to 'think outside the box'
An enhanced facility to process information
The ability to spot misleading arguments

Videos.name: The Circular Argument Fallacy
Videos.description: This is what Anna’s manager said about her bid to be promoted:'I will not be supporting Anna for promotion to management level.  She doesn’t have enough visibility or backing at management level.'  The problem with this reasoning is that it’s circular...a kind of logical fallacy.

Videos.name: Fundamental Attribution Error
Videos.description: We're going to examine a cognitive bias called the Fundamental Attribution Error.  It’s called ‘fundamental’ because it’s really basic and common…. ‘attribution’ because it’s about attributing blame… and ‘error’ because it’s a big mistake to make.  Watch the video to discover more...

Videos.name: Ad Hominem
Videos.description: This name comes from the Latin and translates as 'On The Man'.  So instead of attacking the argument we attack the man who makes it.

Videos.name: Straw Man Fallacy
Videos.description: A 'Straw Man' is a pretend or imaginary enemy.  Soldiers training for battle may use a human figure made of straw as a target for practice.  Unsurprisingly, they find it easy to destroy the man made out of straw.  in an argument, a straw man is a false version of your opponent’s position...

Videos.name: Confirmation Bias
Videos.description: Confirmation Bias is the tendency to look for – and accept – evidence that seems to support our existing beliefs and to dismiss evidence against.  Examples have been found in every professional area…

Videos.name: Reversion to the Mean
Videos.description: If you have a background in statistics you’re probably familiar with the concept of reversion (return) to the mean (or average) as something we are likely to see over time.  In business we have to beware of setting store by this phenomenon.

Videos.name: The Gamblers Fallacy
Videos.description: Perhaps the most common fallacy in our reasoning about probability is the Gambler’s Fallacy which is the belief that if something hasn’t happened for a long time it's bound to happen soon.  But is this true?

Videos.name: Causes and Correlations
Videos.description: When two things occur together, that is called correlation.  However, It may be that neither of the two things causes the other, and in fact are both being caused by some third force.  This video looks at how making an incorrect assumption of the cause of something at work, can lead to errors being made.

Videos.name: The Self-fulfilling Prophecy
Videos.description: We all need to be aware of the phenomenon of the self-fulfilling prophecy – a prediction that causes itself to come true – it's well attested, with countless examples in practice.

Videos.name: A False Dichotomy - Part 1
Videos.description: Speakers use False Dichotomy when they want to shake people out of a neutral position by saying that a neutral position is impossible.  Of course, they know that a neutral position IS possible.  What they're really saying is that the neutral position is unacceptable...

Videos.name: A False Dichotomy - Part 2
Videos.description: A False Dichotomy also lies at the root of the problem when people are being unassertive.  To be unassertive is to feel that you have to choose between saying what you think and keeping people happy. That’s a false dichotomy because those are not the only two choices...

Videos.name: The Baltimore Stockbroker
Videos.description: The Baltimore Stockbroker is a scam that you are most likely to fall for by pulling in on yourself.  The reason why people fall for it is their tendency to see causal relationships in random events.

Videos.name: Argument from Anecdote
Videos.description: An Argument from Anecdote is at once one of the weakest arguments you can use as well as being one of the most powerfully persuasive arguments – which sounds like a contradiction.  But the fact is our logical minds and emotional minds have different ways of working and we need to be aware of basing our general beliefs on just one story – as this video illustrates.

Videos.name: The Missing Premise
Videos.description: Now in this video we’re going to look at something that is common to many fallacies, and also explains why most of the time we're not sure when faced with fallacious reasoning, which fallacy it actually it is.

Videos.name: Appeal to Nature
Videos.description: The Appeal To Nature is when someone claims that something is good because it's natural, or bad because it's unnatural.  This video examines how this can occur in the workplace.

Videos.name: False Linear Thinking
Videos.description: Be careful of any conclusion that says ‘If current trends continue…’.  The whole point about trends is that they rarely continue.  They are current trends.  This video explains how to avoid the error and to look for evidence to help you decide whether the rising trend you’re looking at is a small part of a straight line, a small part of a curve, or even just a random blip.

Videos.name: No True Scotsman
Videos.description: The No True Scotsman argument is one where we have made a generalisation and then, when someone comes up with a counterexample, we dismiss it by saying that the counterexample is not a real example of the kind of thing we were talking about.

Videos.name: The Halo Effect
Videos.description: The Halo Effect is when someone is good in one area, we naturally assume they will be good in another, and vice-versa – even if there is no good reason to make that assumption.

Videos.name: Necessary and Sufficient Conditions
Videos.description: The word ‘IF’ in the English language is ambiguous.  'Marcus will go to the party if Stephanie goes'.  Surely that means that whether Marcus goes to the party depends on if Stephanie is going, and if she doesn’t go, Marcus won’t?  However, Marcus will also go to the party IF Marianne goes.  That's why it's important to make clear whether we’re talking about necessary or sufficient conditions.

Videos.name: The Slippery Slope Fallacy
Videos.description: A Slippery Slope Argument (also known as a Thin End of the Wedge Argument) is when we say that by taking such and such a step we will tread on a slippery slope and slide all the way down to the bottom.  Some Slippery Slope arguments are fallacies – you need to know how to tell which.

Videos.name: Loaded Question
Videos.description: Here's a loaded question: 'Have you stopped lying on your tax return?'  If you answer 'Yes', it sounds as if you’ve been lying on your tax return.  And if you say 'No', it sounds as if you still do it.  Clearly, loaded questions can be hard to spot and to defend yourself against.

Videos.name: Social Proof
Videos.description: Social Proof is a cognitive bias that states that what a large number of people believe must be correct.  The trouble is, it can also be a logical fallacy.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: This final video summarises what we’ve covered in the videos.  First of all, critical thinking means looking for possible sources of error – in your own thinking, just as much as other people’s. Things we should look out for are: Bias, Fallacy, Causes, Confirming your own false beliefs, Being a good listener...

Courses.intro_description: Put simply, Critical Thinking is the art of not thinking wrongly.  In particular it's the ability to spot arguments that, deliberately or not, are misleading.  If you’re thinking critically you realise what knowledge you don’t have, what might be biasing your thinking, and what a persuasive sounding argument actually proves.
Courses.name: Critical Thinking
Courses.description: Learn to spot misleading arguments and to discover the knowledge you don't have, but need.

Headings.text: To ignore office politics is unwise
High self-esteem leads to high success
To become more present & more at ease
To  learn techniques & examine your thinking
To silence your inner negative monologue
To focus more on the greatness of others
To be more aware of yourself
Freedom from the judgments of others

Videos.name: Influencing Correctly
Videos.description: How can you influence correctly and effectively?  First it’s worth recognising where you stand on this matter: some people say they're no good at office politics.  Or that they let their work speak for itself, and don’t want to get involved in game playing.  They don’t think it’s right.  We’ll look at where this puts you on the scale of office politics.

Videos.name: Good Politics
Videos.description: People often refer to individuals who are good at office politics in a derogatory way, but with a slight hint of jealousy, because their innate abilities often help them get ahead.  When challenges come up, or disagreements occur, these people are naturally able to read the situation quickly and accurately.

Videos.name: Bad Politics
Videos.description: The results of bad office politics can often be disruptive, and even damaging.  People who practice poor forms of office politics tend to be excellent at managing up the line because that’s where they're putting most of their focus. They can often be seen sucking up to seniors.

Videos.name: The Middle Ground
Videos.description: The most important aspect of being truly good at office politics, is to focus on authentic relationship-building first and foremost.  One of the biggest hallmarks of a good relationship-builder is understanding how different people operate, and communicating with them in ways that empower and resonate.

Videos.name: Four Ways to Tackle Difficult Behaviour
Videos.description: There are many ways of looking at office behaviour, but perhaps the most insightful is taken from Jane Clark's book 'Savvy'. In it, she helps categorise the different behaviours you may see at the office, in an effort to uncover best practices.  Clark divides political behaviour into two main categories: the methods used by the individual, and their motives.

Videos.name: Dealing with Naives
Videos.description: Naives have good intentions, but without the corresponding skills.  However, When Naives encounter conflict they can be sharp to deal with.  They may be overly direct, get passionate about issues, and not effectively influence those around them.  Their heart's in the right place, but their execution is clumsy.

Videos.name: Dealing with Barbarians
Videos.description: Barbarians are quite easy to identify because they’re so obvious about it. They’re rude, difficult, often insecure, and they tend to belittle other people.  When you have to work with Barbarians, or report to them, the best thing is to confront their behaviour head on.

Videos.name: Dealing with Machiavellians
Videos.description: The unfortunate thing about Machiavellians is that their activities are much more subtle and hard to detect than Barbarians’.  There’s often a nagging suspicion that something is 'off', but the tendency is to give the Machiavellian the benefit of the doubt, because often there’s nothing specific to point to.

Videos.name: Dealing with Stars
Videos.description: Stars are often described as good leaders, resourceful, well networked, popular. They're very good at negotiating around the office and getting things done with aplomb.  Observe how Stars operate, and learn from them, so you have valuable resources and tools for your own growth.

Videos.name: The Importance of Being Political Savvy - Introduction
Videos.description: Let's take a pause at this point and think about why being political savvy, and learning to deal with various personalities and behaviours is so important in today’s global marketplace.  There’s a lot more focus on what each individual contributes to the workforce, and It’s no longer enough to simply be good at your job.

Videos.name: Toxic Environments
Videos.description: Without good office politics, it’s highly likely that a work environment could become toxic. There are particular conditions that could lead a workplace to become toxic, either within teams, departments or across the organisation more broadly.  This video examines some of the most common conditions to look out for.

Videos.name: Blame Culture
Videos.description: In the workplace, focussing solely on someone’s actions, and ignoring the circumstances, intentions, or character of the person can promote the idea that tough sanctions for misdemeanours will improve performance, and that firm discipline will 'focus the mind'.

Videos.name: Understanding Herd Mentality
Videos.description: It’s a natural human tendency to form groups in which we feel comfortable and understand the basic structures. Achieving this level of comfort is an important developmental process for any group but can take a bit of getting used to.
