When working in a group, it’s important to know when to lead and when to follow.

Videos.name: Symptoms of Office Politics
Videos.description: There are some obvious signs that you’re caught in negative office politics.  Look for these signs:  Feeling caught in the middle of different factions | People stealing credit that you should receive | People encroaching on your territory | Feeling like you’re dealing with hidden agendas | Being held back from opportunities, projects, or promotions.

Videos.name: Introduction to In-groups
Videos.description: Who holds the power in any new group, and how can you tell?  Being able to interpret power dynamics quickly is a key skill to develop when new groups form. Use these categories to assess power structures, and understand who fits in where.

Videos.name: Seeing the Warning Signs
Videos.description: According to Rob Kendall, in his book 'Blamestorming', there are five clear warning signs that a situation is about to go South; this video pinpoints them.

Videos.name: Strategies for Neutralising Hazardous Behaviour
Videos.description: If you’re caught working in an environment where there’s some hazardous behaviour, it can be useful to have these tools under your belt.

Videos.name: Building the Case
Videos.description: When dealing with office politics the best way to cut through any of the game-playing is to clearly state that you understand the problem at hand, and then be able to back up and support your argument.  We call this Building the case.

Videos.name: Be the One Who Asks Questions
Videos.description: In times of conflict a lot of people will clam up when there's a heated discussion and try to be invisible.  Instead, be the one who asks questions.

Videos.name: How to Handle Other People's Anger
Videos.description: There are two types of anger: justified anger and tactical anger.  Justified anger, is exactly that, it’s justified. Another person has taken umbrage with something you've done or said. Then there's Tactical anger that's manipulative, and is used to get you to do something, or get a reaction out of you.

Videos.name: Tackling Difficult Behaviour
Videos.description: This video looks at four ways of tackling difficult behaviour.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: This series of videos has looked at office politics, identifying different behaviours and how to deal with them.  It's important to acknowledge office politics.  Rather than shying away from these activities it's vital you understand how to work with the power structures in your organisation and how to influence and get things done in the right way.  This final course video contains a useful summary.

Courses.intro_description: The law in the UK prescribes that employers provide training for all employees who have to deal with Hazardous substances.  It’s called COSHH training. However, there is no such law for taking care of employees who work in office environments where they may find themselves dealing with hazardous people, situations or behaviour.
Courses.name: Navigating Office Politics
Courses.description: Discover the middle ground of office politics by building authentic relationships first and foremost.

Headings.text: Confident people are a valuable asset
High self-esteem leads to high success
To become more present & more at ease
To  learn techniques & examine your thinking
To silence your inner negative monologue
To focus more on the greatness of others
To be more aware of yourself
Freedom from the judgments of others

Videos.name: Introduction to The Power of Presence
Videos.description: Being the loudest in the room doesn't make you the most confident. Voice coach and author, Patsy Rodenburg puts this best by describing how we’re always in one of three circles of presence.

Videos.name: Where is Your Focus?
Videos.description: We have a voice in our heads - the inner monologue that constantly comments on how we feel. The trouble is, this voice loves to focus on the negative, basing its opinion largely on inappropriate measures such as our fears and emotional state.

Videos.name: Be Nice and Compliment
Videos.description: Many of us focus on what we perceive as the negative side of our looks and personality. When we look in the mirror we search for the blemish. Of course, this can lower confidence and self-esteem.  To help change a negative mindset, we must first notice the greatness of others, and in turn ourselves.

Videos.name: How to Respond to a Compliment
Videos.description: We all like to be praised, and yet how easy is it to deflect a compliment or even outright refuse it?  Simply accepting a compliment can go a long way to improving your confidence.

Videos.name: How Often Do You Say Sorry?
Videos.description: For many of us, saying the word 'sorry' doesn't necessarily mean we’re feeling apologetic. It’s a word that we just mysteriously mutter when someone accidentally bumps into us, or sometimes randomly at the beginning of a sentence.  Start noticing every time you use the word “sorry” and ask yourself, “Did I actually do anything wrong?”

Videos.name: Talk to More People
Videos.description: One of the greatest ways of developing your confidence is simply to get out there and meet new people. You can try to meet someone new every day or start conversations by simply saying 'hello'...

Videos.name: It's All in The Smile
Videos.description: When you smile, the world smiles too. That’s because mirror neurons in the brain make us smile in return. Prompting others to smile will make you more cheerful and relaxed. Research shows that smiling lowers the heart rate and helps you cope more effectively in stressful situations...

Chapters.name: Fake It until You Make It

Videos.name: The Power Pose
Videos.description: Our body and mind are intrinsically connected. The way we stand, walk or hold ourselves changes the way we feel. For example, the Power Pose is used by people in need of instant confidence – before an interview, before delivering a presentation.

Videos.name: The Posture Exercise Plan
Videos.description: We hear it all the time – sit up straight if you want to come across well. Stand tall if you want to be taken seriously.  Does slouching really have a negative effect?.  According to a review of more than 100 studies, poor posture can be linked to: breathing problems | falls | depression.

Videos.name: The Big Grin
Videos.description: Ever find yourself in a mood where whatever happens, it’s bad news? You turn up to work and the smallest thing can feel like the world is about to end? Here’s a very simple exercise to help you build back your self esteem. An exercise you won’t believe until you try, and one you must commit to for it to work.

Videos.name: Visualisation
Videos.description: Visualisation is the act of imagining yourself undertaking an upcoming task and watching your future performance from the comfort of your own mind. Athletes use this technique regularly...

Videos.name: Who is Your  Confidence Role Model?
Videos.description: Confidence isn't an unattainable goal owned by others. Instead, think of confidence as a result of many different factors. To have true confidence we must break down what these factors are and 'fake it, until we make it'.

Videos.name: Are You Breathing?
Videos.description: The secret to deep breath, and true relaxation, is hidden in the term “deep breath”.

Videos.name: It's in the Environment
Videos.description: We all tend to change depending on who we’re with and the environment we’re in.

Videos.name: The Pep Talk
Videos.description: The Pep Talk. You might have seen other people giving themselves a good talking to in front of the mirror before a big event, either in films or in real life. But have you ever done it?  It may seem silly, but it’s a habit worth acquiring.

Videos.name: Get Active
Videos.description: Confidence and self esteem are connected to physical activity. There are countless studies connecting happiness to exercise, and most of us can appreciate the benefits – the difficulty is finding the self-motivation to get those running shoes on.

Videos.name: Observe and Admire
Videos.description: According to a recent study, when we judge ourselves we’re likely to do the same to others and take to heart what they say about us. All this judgement makes sustaining self-confidence difficult as it puts emotional, reactionary barriers in the way of gaining greater self control over your self-belief.

Videos.name: Three Good Things
Videos.description: Research has shown hat gratitude is vital to how good we feel both socially and psychologically. It raises overall satisfaction with life and helps create an overall positive outlook. Not only that, gratitude is linked to an increase in the ability to achieve our goals.

Videos.name: A Positive Note
Videos.description: People will often say good things about you, your work or attitude. But do you really hear them? The power of noting positive feedback in both home and work life can be incredibly rewarding – and will help you to achieve a healthier opinion of yourself.

Videos.name: Your Are What You Eat
Videos.description: When you have a good, balanced diet you are more likely feel balanced in yourself, and to have control over your feelings and actions. And some researchers think there’s a direct link between diet and serotonin levels.

Videos.name: Your Confidence Buddy
Videos.description: Some mornings we wake up and don’t feel comfortable in our own skins. It could be because something important is coming up, or we slept poorly, or we might be brooding about the way someone spoke to us the day before.  Talking though how we’re feeling with someone we trust can help change our mindset quickly.

Videos.name: Pump Up The Music
Videos.description: We’ve all seen it, the athletes before a race, preparing for their moment of glory. Have you noticed how many of them are wearing headphones, eyes closed or steely in focus, gently nodding away to music? They seem to be pumping themselves up, with the intention of winning – of success.

Videos.name: Dress to Impress
Videos.description: Dress to impress. An obvious solution that’s often forgotten when we have lower self-esteem. However, dressing well makes it easier for us to feel good. We can look in the mirror and see the most confident version of ourselves.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: Welcome to the last video of this course.  Remember, confidence is a result of your behaviours.  If you wish to better your confidence and self-esteem, you must first change the way you behave.  Watch this short film for a recap of the key areas to address.

Courses.intro_description: Having confidence and self esteem is not a skill, but is a result of our behaviours. When we stand tall, we feel taller. When we bring positivity to others, we feel positive about ourselves. This course breaks down and examines what the key behaviours to building confidence are.
Courses.name: Confidence and Self-Esteem
Courses.description: Boost the way you feel in yourself and around other people.

Headings.text: To build bonds with those you interact with
It's a vital feature of human interaction
Of other people's views of the world
What to do when it's not
All parts of you, working in harmony
You, seeing eye-to-eye with more people

Videos.name: Attitude
Videos.description: Before we can get into the mechanics of rapport building there’s one vital step you must take. That is to commit to the act of building rapport. By that we mean you have to have the right attitude and dedicate yourself to building rapport whenever you can, with whoever you can.

Videos.name: Observation
Videos.description: We’d like you to undertake an exercise. It’s simply one of observation. The next meeting or event you attend, observe the interactions that are taking place. Which ones are working and which ones aren’t?  Try to identify the reasons.

Videos.name: The Theory of Reciprocity
Videos.description: Sticking with the notion of becoming conscious of the mechanics of rapport and developing the right attitude, this video looks at why rapport is such a big part of human communication.

Videos.name: The Gift of Being Present
Videos.description: When we’re not present to the person we’re speaking to, rapport becomes a fragile thing...

Videos.name: It's Not About You
Videos.description: We’ve established that reciprocity is the foundation of rapport and being present to the person you’re speaking with is what creates the connection. It therefore follows that in order to maintain rapport, you have to be focused on the other person.

Videos.name: Effective Questions
Videos.description: It’s important to build your questioning skills because questions are the fuel that keeps a conversation going. In addition, they’re the element that drives reciprocity. If you ask someone a question, you’re demonstrating an interest in them. That in turn will lead them to want to engage more with you – thus the conversation continues and rapport builds.

Videos.name: The Selfish Question
Videos.description: A question asked and then answered by the questioner is a rapport killer and gives the impression of selfishness.

Videos.name: Listening to Understand, Not Simply to Reply
Videos.description: Many people confuse the act of listening with hearing, but hearing doesn’t  mean you’re necessarily listening.

Videos.name: Empathy
Videos.description: By listening empathically, you understand more about the person you’re talking to. By understanding more, you’re more insightful in the conversation. And it’s this sense of insight that creates strong connections.

Videos.name: What’s In A Name  Part 1?
Videos.description: Remembering someone’s name and saying it in conversation is a simple, yet highly effective way of building rapport. But why is that?

Videos.name: What’s In A Name  Part 2?
Videos.description: Here are some simple techniques for remembering names.

Videos.name: Recap
Videos.description: In the second half of this course we’re going to explore the physical elements of rapport building. Before we do, lets recap on the key points from the course so far.

Videos.name: Window to the Soul
Videos.description: There's an old proverb that says the eyes are the window to the soul. Throughout classical and modern scientific study, the eyes have been recognised as highly sophisticated communication tools.

Videos.name: Smile
Videos.description: When someone smiles it often puts us at ease. We feel that if a person is smiling at us they’re happy and comfortable. And if they’re happy and comfortable then we should be to. It’s an incredibly quick win in the rapport building process, yet so many people fail to employ it.

Videos.name: Body Language
Videos.description: American poet Ralph Waldo Emerson once said, “your actions speak so loud, I cannot hear what you are saying”. Never has a truer word been said about the power of non-verbal communication, or body language as it's better known.

Videos.name: Energy and Balance
Videos.description: To achieve the right level of energy you need to assess the character and personality style of the person or people you’re speaking to. Then think about your own style. How can you flex it to achieve balance with them?

Videos.name: Voice
Videos.description: We’ve explored the need to adopt the right level of energy in a conversation and often it’s the voice that delivers that energy. Too monotone or quiet and we struggle to stay in the conversation. To create engagement you need to use tonal variation.

Videos.name: Meeting
Videos.description: Building rapport when you’re in the same room as the other person is one thing. It’s a somewhat different matter if they’re halfway across the world. As communication technology becomes more sophisticated, more of us are having virtual meetings and conversations...

Videos.name: Telephone
Videos.description: For many people their primary business communication tool is the telephone. Entire working relationships can be conducted without ever meeting someone and this is particularly true of international relationships.

Videos.name: Email
Videos.description: Email is a totally man-made solution to communicate across time and space. Because there’s no visual or vocal connection, it’s easy to lose humanity when we communicate like this. But that doesn’t have to be the case.

Videos.name: Building Rapport with Senior People
Videos.description: How do you build rapport with senior people? Or let's just call them 'people'. Because that’s the first thing to recognise. They may have seniority in a business but first and foremost – they’re people.

Videos.name: The Long Game
Videos.description: Rapport is not something that happens overnight. Certainly there are people you click with almost immediately, but for the majority you need to get to know them and build connections over time. That’s why rapport building is a long-term investment.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: This final video from the Building Rapport course is an excellent summary of all the takeaways.

Courses.intro_description: We all know that to get on in business and in life we have to communicate effectively with people. If we fail to build bonds with those we interact with, life becomes that much more difficult. So building rapport is critical to success. But what is it?
Courses.name: Building Rapport
Courses.description: Connect meaningfully with others whilst build trust and understanding to create better relationships.

Headings.text: Stories reveal far more than the facts
Can make us feel feel hopeful & optimistic
Story can be practically applied in business
The three ancient pillars of persuasion
How to reach the audience's emotions
Greater airtime with customers and colleagues

Videos.name: Introduction to Aristotle’s Three Pillars of Persuasion
Videos.description: 2300 years ago, the Greek philosopher Aristotle defined the three pillars to being persuasive. They’re as tried and true today as they were back in ancient times.

Videos.name: Ethos - The First Pillar
Videos.description: Before we can convince anyone to accept anything we say, we have to be perceived as trustworthy. If we move too early to the facts of a speech, without establishing trust, we actually diminish our credibility rather than increase it.

Videos.name: Logos - The Second Pillar
Videos.description: Logos stories are anecdotes, or arguments based in logic. In fact many linguists believe that the word 'logic' is derived from the Greek word logos. To use logos in storytelling would be to cite facts and statistics, historical and literal analogies, and authorities.

Videos.name: Pathos - The Third Pillar - Part 1
Videos.description: Pathos stories are a path to the audience’s emotions. Pathos works in conjunction with logos (logic) and ethos (credibility) to help form a solid argument. Used correctly, pathos can make a bland argument come alive for an audience.

Videos.name: Pathos - The Third Pillar - Part 2
Videos.description: Pathos can make a bland argument come alive for your audience. It offers a way for the audience to relate to the subject through commonly held emotions.

Videos.name: Story Archetypes in History
Videos.description: In his book, 'The Seven Basic Plots: Why We Tell Stories' author Christopher Booker defines seven archetypical structures that are the foundation of any plot.  These plots date back to cave drawings, appear throughout literature and are ever-present in movies and television.

Videos.name: Story Structure in Five Acts
Videos.description: In the mid 1880’s, German playwright and Novelist Gustav Freytag set out to define a plot structure for an effective story. He crafted a story structure into 5 acts.  Today, many writers consider Freytag’s structure an excellent springboard to crafting story and although based on plays, it can be applied and modified to stories as well.

Videos.name: Stories in a Business Context - Part 1
Videos.description: There’s a Native American proverb that says, “Those who tell the stories rule the world.” People aren’t moved to action by data dumping, dense slides, or spreadsheets packed with numbers. People are often moved by context, and a richer understanding of what the facts actually mean.

Videos.name: Stories in a Business Context - Part 2
Videos.description: In this video we look at some additional stories that apply in a business context.

Videos.name: Story Writing is a Creative Endeavour
Videos.description: In business, we write with the goal of being clear in order to communicate information effectively.  In order to craft an effective story however, one’s imagination, feelings, descriptions, vivid imagery and metaphors are needed to make it interesting. And structure is important as well.

Videos.name: Metaphor, Smile and Analogy
Videos.description: Shakespeare was a master at creating powerful metaphors that allow us to make the complex, simple, relatable, and interesting. Metaphor, simile, and anecdote are all part of the story tellers tool kit. They can evoke images, feelings, and clarify the conceptual, to a human level we can all relate to.

Videos.name: Engage Through the Senses
Videos.description: When we use the language of the senses, we invite vivid sensory experiences into the minds of our listeners. Did you ever get goose bumps as a child hearing a scary story around a campfire? Or begin to salivate at the description of a piece of chocolate cake? Or weep at the death of a character in a novel?

Videos.name: Believing Your Story and Delivery
Videos.description: “Tell the truth, it’s the easier thing to remember,” wrote American playwright David Mamet.  This rings true when it comes to both: How we relate to what we say - and how we say it to others.  When we tell a story that we’ve experienced, we’re in a much deeper relationship to our content

Videos.name: Vision Story Structure
Videos.description: Those who wish to communicate vision must use a three-step process: First, define a vision. Second, share that vision with others. And third, inspire others to support that vision.

Videos.name: Tips for Storytelling and Crafting
Videos.description: Here is a collection of final tips to help craft your story.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: Now is the time to put theory into practice. Here we recap the best process to follow to create a story. Step one is to decide the kind of story you want to tell...

Courses.intro_description: Stories make our presentations better. Stories stick. They help to motivate, persuade, build alignment amongst teams, warn, entertain, enlighten, educate and inspire audiences to action.  They appeal to the heart and the head and reveal far more than the facts.
Courses.name: Storytelling for Business
Courses.description: Grip your audience with stories that influence, inspire and motivate.

Headings.text: In a sense, we are all in sales…
But what drives people to buy?
And understand the importance of trust
The five key steps to a buying decision
You with the knowledge and tools to…

Videos.name: Understanding the Concept of Utility
Videos.description: Whether you’re selling a specific product, service, concept or idea, if you're going to successfully persuade or influence the motivations or actions of others, you need to first understand what drives a person to buy in the first place.

Videos.name: Introduction to Customer Buying
Videos.description: The Customer Buying Process is a sequence of steps that a person goes through to arrive at a final decision when buying a product, service, concept or idea.

Videos.name: Recognition of the Problem or Need
Videos.description: This is where the customer recognises that they have a specific problem or need they would like to be addressed or satisfied.  A buying decision cannot be made unless there is acknowledgement that a problem or need exists.

Videos.name: Information Search
Videos.description: The second step in the Customer Buying Process is the Information Search. This is the customer's effort to search for information that relates to fixing their problem or need.

Videos.name: Evaluate Options
Videos.description: The third step in the Customer Buying Process is Evaluating Options. At this stage, the customer uses the information gathered in Step Two to evaluate their possible options, with the intent of selecting one that they believe best addresses their problem or achieves their need.

Videos.name: Make the Decision
Videos.description: The fourth step in the Customer Buying Process is Making the Decision. At this point, the customer has evaluated their options, and are now deciding whether to move forward with it or not.

Videos.name: Post Decision Evaluation
Videos.description: The fifth and final step in the Customer Buying Process is the Post Decision Evaluation.  This is where the customer compares the outcome of their decision against their original expectations.

Videos.name: Introduction to The Four Key Stakeholders
Videos.description: In addition to understanding the sequential steps that a customer goes through when they make a buying decision, another key driver to sales success is to fully understand the different people who may be involved in the buying process.

Videos.name: The Decider and The Influencer
Videos.description: In this video we will be exploring two different stakeholder roles – the Decider and the Influencer.  Let’s start by exploring the role of the Decider, probably the most integral person to have on your side.

Videos.name: The Buyer and The User
Videos.description: The Buyer is the person who is going to ultimately write the check or pay the bill.  Generally, the Buyer trusts the Decider to make the best decision.

Videos.name: Stakeholder Activity Actions
Videos.description: Now that we’ve explored the different stakeholder roles that may make an appearance within the buying process, let’s take this learning and apply it practically.

Videos.name: Introduction to Mastering the Skills of Attunement
Videos.description: In his book, 'To Sell is Human', Daniel Pink explains that in order to be successful at influencing the actions and motivations of others, an essential quality that salespeople need to master is attunement –  the ability to bring one’s actions and outlook into harmony with other people.

Videos.name: Types of Questions
Videos.description: The quality and outcome of a sales conversion can be significantly influenced by the questions asked by the salesperson.  There are a range of different types of questions that a salesperson can use and this video explores them.

Videos.name: Introduction to the SPIN Model
Videos.description: Now that we've explored the different types of questions, we introduce you to a more advance questioning model called the SPIN model.

Videos.name: Situation Questions
Videos.description: Situational questions are designed to gather facts and valuable information about the customer’s existing situation.  They help build a clear picture of what’s going on in your customer’s world, so you can determine if your product, service, concept or idea will be of value to them.

Videos.name: Problem Questions
Videos.description: Problem questions probe for problems, difficulties or general areas of dissatisfaction that the customer is having.  Answers to the problem will direct you towards the root cause of the customer’s needs.

Videos.name: Implication Questions
Videos.description: Implication questions are designed get the customer eager to find a solution to their problem.  Smart implication questions will make the customer identify for themselves the impact the problem creates if it continues.

Videos.name: Need or Pay-Off Questions
Videos.description: Need or Pay-Off questions get the customer thinking about the value, importance and usefulness of your solution.

Videos.name: Effective Listening
Videos.description: Another fundamental skill that is required to master the art of ‘attunement’ is the ability to effectively listen.  And though this may seem obvious, genuinely listening to another person can be harder than it sounds.

Videos.name: The Importance of Trust in Sales
Videos.description: Trust is the foundation to any successful relationship, sales or otherwise. A lack of trust can put everything in the customer buying process into question and speculation.

Videos.name: The Trust Equation Explained
Videos.description: Achieving a high level of trust in relationships is fundamental to success in how we do business today. The level of trust in business relationships, whether they're internal with employees or colleagues, or external with customers and partners, is the greatest determinant of sales success.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: Having developed a high level of trust with your customer through implementing the principles of the Trust Equation, you will now be in a strong position to pitch your proposed solution to them.  High performing sales people often use a technique called an Elevator Pitch at this point.

Courses.intro_description: Daniel Pink, author of the book ‘To Sell is Human’, along with a cluster of other economic and social experts, conducted some interesting research that challenges our thinking about sales.  What the research illustrates is that we are all in sales as a result of being human.
Courses.name: Psychology of Sales
Courses.description: To sell more, learn how buyers think.

Headings.text: This practise can reduce stress by 20%
And boost the immune system by 25%
How to integrate it into your life
Different techniques for its regular use
You, making better, less hasty decisions
A calmer and more focussed you
A happier and more peaceful you

Videos.name: What is it?
Videos.description: Jon Kabat-Zinn, creator of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction, defines Mindfulness as 'Paying attention in a particular way; on purpose, in the present moment, and non judgmentally.”

Videos.name: Why Use it?
Videos.description: The research is clear: only a few minutes of a Mindfulness practise can improve your immune system and reduce stress by more than 20% - without changing the circumstances of your work and personal life.

Videos.name: Breaking Habits
Videos.description: We’re creatures of habit. We create and act upon familiar and habitual thoughts and behavioural patterns. Once these habits are formed, they’re really hard to challenge and change.

Videos.name: The Amygdala
Videos.description: A growing number of neuroscience studies have shown the impact a Mindfulness practice has on key areas of the brain. This video explains the particular effect a mindfulness practise has on the Amygdala - and why that matters.

Videos.name: The ACC and the Insula
Videos.description: A Mindfulness practice has been shown to result in an increase in grey matter within the ACC, the executive centre of the brain.  It’s the job of the ACC to tone down the reactivity of the Amygdala, and to help us make decisions in a more balanced and informed way.

Videos.name: Innovative Thinking
Videos.description: Innovative thinking is the ability to have a different and unique perspective on problems and challenges; it’s the ability to be creative and inventive and to assume an observer position – one that is less emotional and involves more advanced areas of the brain.

Videos.name: Body Scan
Videos.description: In this video, we’re going to demonstrate a short version of the Body Scan. We’ll perform a quick sweep, using our breath as a guide, starting from the feet and going through each area of the body.

Videos.name: The Breath
Videos.description: Following on from the Body Scan of the last video, we’ll continue with some short Mindfulness practices. These are designed to increase 'groundedness', and to help anchor you in the present moment, thus creating a strong base from which to venture out and begin to change habits.

Videos.name: Grounding Objects
Videos.description: Focussing on the breath is not always easy, and a reminder is often needed to help the mind from wandering too far astray.  A Grounding Object can help.

Videos.name: Disrupting Habitual Thought Patterns and Belief Systems
Videos.description: Our thoughts are often disguised as facts, and we tend to buy into their meaning. Because of this, we often act on these thoughts impulsively and instantaneously.

Videos.name: 3 Minute Breathing Space
Videos.description: The 3-Minute Breathing Space is a short version of the formal Mindfulness practice, and is the essence of all Mindfulness practices.

Videos.name: How to Integrate it in Your Life
Videos.description: The best part about Mindfulness is that it can be integrated into every aspect of your life – starting with the smallest activities, and gradually expanding into other more challenging areas until a formal practice is mixed with every activity at work and in your personal life.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: Now please take the exercises outlined in this video series and put them into practice as often as you can. Notice the changes in your levels of happiness and satisfaction and begin to track your success at work. Don't be surprised if you noticed a direct correlation between the implementation of a Mindfulness practice and an increase to your happiness and success.

Courses.intro_description: The aim of this course is to introduce you to the immense benefits of Mindfulness.  We’ll explain why Mindfulness has become so popular and teach you how to integrate a Mindfulness practice into your busy everyday life. We’ll also go over the brain science that proves the effectiveness of mindfulness beyond a shadow of a doubt.
Courses.name: Mindfulness for Busy People
Courses.description: Learn how to relax, become present and drop your stress levels by twenty percent.

Headings.text: Having this ability is something we all want
It's something you can learn and improve at
What if you can't think of anything to say?
How to relax and be present under pressure
How to be and appear, congruent
A relaxed and more confident you as well as…
The ability to think nimbly under pressure
A clearer head in trying situations
You coming across as persuasive & trustworthy

Videos.name: How we Think Spontaneously
Videos.description: Writer Malcolm Gladwell looked at a recent Pentagon war game exercise and found that the winning side used far less logical analysis and far more intuition in the way they conducted it.

Videos.name: Being Present
Videos.description: It’s all about owning your space.  When you’re mindful with body language you can maintain your own focus and others’ focus on you.  To own your physical space, align your spine and physically orient yourself openly towards the audience (even if they’re on the phone).  Your presence will grow and your focus sharpen.

Videos.name: Being Relaxed
Videos.description: Relaxation is crucial for Thinking on your Feet. The quickest way to relax, re-centre yourself and maintain focus, is with breathing.  Square breathing is a way to proactively create this state of being.

Videos.name: Brain Science - Part 1
Videos.description: The medial prefrontal cortex is the part of the brain associated with self-expression. Researchers describe this as a mental narrator that keeps tabs on the story of your life. This cortex is closely associated with impulse control, making people think twice before they drink a milkshake, order a third scotch or place a bet at the track – a sort of mental curb that keeps the neurons in line.

Videos.name: Brain Science - Part 2
Videos.description: There are varying levels of depth and involvement to our brainwork when we’re thinking on our feet. Innovation blogger Nick Skillicorn says, “When people are asked to come up with ideas for a challenge, most people’s minds will provide solutions in a sequence'.  This video describes the sequence.

Videos.name: Brain Science - Part 3
Videos.description: Ever had one of those 'eureka moments' of insight that appear to come out of nowhere? Maybe when you’re in the shower or exercising, or just after you’ve woken up? Even though you’re in a relaxed mental state, your brain is evidently still doing work 'offline'. This sometimes results in new ideas you didn’t consciously create.

Videos.name: Brain Science - Part 4
Videos.description: How are ideas formed?  Sometimes slowly and sometimes in the blink of an eye.  Neurologist Vincent Walsh points out that in the brain, Ideas are new connections between separate pieces of existing knowledge and context. Every idea builds somehow on your experiences, memories and current mental activity...

Videos.name: Stress and Self-belief
Videos.description: Legendary Chicago teacher of comedy improvisation Del Close is famous for urging students to, among many other things, “follow the fear.”  Thinking on your Feet with clients, in a pitch, in a difficult conversation or professional confrontation can be scary.  Anger or anxiety can seem to surround us.

Videos.name: The Gut - Part 1
Videos.description: Improvisation guru Keith Johnstone says that someone “whose inspired, is being obvious. He’s not making any decisions, he’s not weighing one idea against another. He’s accepting his first thoughts.”  'Going with the gut' is not appropriate 100% of the time, but it's equally limiting to believe it’s never the way to go...

Videos.name: The Gut - Part 2
Videos.description: 'Going with the gut' can feel like a leap of faith. However, it’s not a reckless, random guess, but a choice to listen to your intuition, to make a holistic assessment, and to heed any hunches you may have.

Videos.name: Notice and Engage
Videos.description: When we’re effectively Thinking on our Feet we’re often simply noticing and wondering.  We see other people in the room and notice their body language, energy, anxiety, pace, breathing and so on.  This video suggests that now is the time we most need to stay open to possibilities...

Videos.name: The Bias Trap - Part 1
Videos.description: In his book 'Blink' one of Malcolm Gladwell’s interview subjects admits “I've served as a judge in auditions listening to musicians without screens, and I can assure you that I was prejudiced. I began to listen with my eyes, and there is no way that your eyes don't affect your judgement. The only true way to listen is with your ears and your heart.”

Videos.name: The Bias Trap - Part 2
Videos.description: Anecdotal and availability bias are often the most common cognitive biases that plague people's reasoning. Anecdotal bias consists of taking evidence from stories that have been 'heard about'. And where only one or a few anecdotes are presented, there's a larger chance they may be unreliable...

Videos.name: Active Answering
Videos.description: British improv guru Keith Johnstone has said “In life, most of us are highly skilled at suppressing action. All the improvisation teacher has to do is to reverse this skill and he creates very gifted improvisers. Bad improvisers block action, often with a high degree of skill. Good improvisers develop action.”

Videos.name: Empathy
Videos.description: Active listeners also use tools like empathy and validation. “What you’re describing sounds incredibly frustrating”, will probably land better than, “Don’t worry about it — you’ve got nothing to be concerned about!”. The latter response shows that you’re pushing ahead to the solution, invalidating their concerns, and not really listening respectfully.

Videos.name: The Power of Saying Yes
Videos.description: You can bolster your active listening by behaving like an improviser.  Improvisers use the core approach of saying and thinking “yes, and…” to offers they hear from others...

Videos.name: Training Going Forward
Videos.description: Our old friend Malcolm Gladwell writes that “Being able to act intelligently and instinctively in the moment is possible only after a long and rigorous course of education and experience”.  We agree, as does Nick Skillicorn.  In this video we recommend several of his short term ways to put your brain into the alpha mental state for divergent thinking.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: In this final video of the course we provide you with some ideas from Lorri Freifeld of the Dale Carnegie Institute.  She suggests suggests there are ways to move from what she calls 'awkward and emotionally constrained' to 'automatic and inspired'.

Courses.intro_description: Thinking on Your Feet, is something we all want to be good at.  It’s about handling surprises, solving problems, being impressive in tricky moments, keeping your cool and being clever.  But it’s usually not about luck, and it’s not simply a talent some clever people are born with.  It’s actually something you can learn, practice, and get better at.
Courses.name: Thinking on Your Feet
Courses.description: Learn the confidence to think differently and surprise the people around you.
Courses.strapline: Cha, cha, cha for the brain.

Headings.text: Non-verbal (NV) communication is a vital skill
NV signals can increase trust & clarity
NV skills will make you a better presenter
How to transmit the right messages
How to use body language (BL) effectively
How to fake it until you make it
The ability to read others' 'hidden' messages
Changing your own mood though your BL

Videos.name: Enzyme Time!
Videos.description: There are many chemical forces at work in us when we think, feel, and communicate.  Let’s examine a few of them right now in the context of body language.

Videos.name: Autonomic System
Videos.description: In his book 'Peoplewatching', Desmond Morris reminds us that “every time we are roused into action a number of basic changes take place in our bodies; the body starts to gear itself up ready for the increased demands that are likely to be put upon it.” There are a few interesting things to know about the nervous system that may help us understand our own and others’ physical reactions.

Videos.name: The Overall Body Position
Videos.description: There are four types of behaviour in social and working life: aggressive, manipulative, submissive and assertive. We see them everywhere in every culture.

Videos.name: Direction
Videos.description: This video examines the ways in which body language serves as a guide to those with whom we're communicating.

Videos.name: Energy
Videos.description: Energy has a lot to do with body language.  We know how it feels when we're low-energy or bored, but we may not be fully conscious of how body language is an active choice in guiding an audience.

Videos.name: Social Displays
Videos.description: As humans, there are actions we're taught through socialisation that we learn very young.  As we mature and acquire a greater sense of choice, we develop certain intentional performances, what Desmond Morris and other theorists call 'social greetings' or 'social displays'.  They convey our degree of social interest and investment and this video looks at how they work.

Videos.name: Unconscious Body Language
Videos.description: We all recognise many of the unconscious body language behaviours known as 'Stress Indicators'. Desmond Morris catalogs some in his book 'Peoplewatching':odd facial expressions, yawns, avoiding eye contact, glazed expressions, grinding teeth, flushing, sweating.  This video goes into the detail.

Videos.name: Mirror
Videos.description: Whenever we meet someone at a table, are standing with others in an elevator, or walking side-by-side, we're subtly adjusting our sense of synchronisation and parity — how closely or how far apart we remain, whether our limbs are extending forward and/or backward in synch.  Even whether we have folded arms or legs or are sitting up at the same angle...

Videos.name: Introduction to Wielding Power
Videos.description: John French and Bertram Raven spent many years researching how people in positions of official power use Body Language to enhance that power.  This video also highlights how such people use it to encourage, reward and coerce.

Videos.name: Position Power
Videos.description: Scientists have spent centuries researching how people in positions of official power, with titles, use body language to enhance that power — or perhaps misuse their body language and undermine themselves.

Videos.name: Coercive and Reward Power
Videos.description: Desmond Morris defines Coercive Power at work as “the ability of the manager to force/coerce/threaten others into doing what he [or she] wants”.

Videos.name: Expert Power
Videos.description: Experts remind us that we tend to give credibility to, and obey others if we believe they have expertise. Body language can portray expertise, especially in the form of confidence or assertiveness. This is called Expert Power.

Videos.name: Dominant Body Language
Videos.description: Desmond Morris and other researchers tell us that the person who is dominant in the conversation will often bring this about by using status displays. One example is that the dominant person may spend more time looking at the person who they wish to feel submissive whilst they are talking to them, than they do while they are listening to them.

Videos.name: Submissive Body Language
Videos.description: Desmond Morris says that passive submission, when extreme, can take the form of cringing, crouching, whimpering and attempting to protect the most vulnerable parts of the body.  As animals, submission presents a picture of our instant defeat or surrender – the supplicant in so doing, thereby hoping to avoid the damaging physical ordeal of actual defeat.

Videos.name: Charisma
Videos.description: Charisma, or what body language scholars call Referent Power exists in the eyes of the beholder, and we can see the effects of someone’s charisma in the body language of others around them. For example when an important, charismatic Managing Director enters a room, others may go silent...

Videos.name: Rapport
Videos.description: How does body language help us build a bridge with someone in the first moments?  Theorists provide helpful insights in the following video.

Videos.name: Public to Intimate
Videos.description: Body language theorists tell us that we can usually tell how close people are in relationship just by observing. As their bond strengthens, the layers of workplace body language become more intimate.  The following video explores this theme.

Videos.name: Head and Face
Videos.description: This video describes a range of head and facial body movements that are very revealing.

Videos.name: The Smile
Videos.description: We know a sincere smile when we see it, and we likely smile dozens of times a day — consciously and unconsciously.  This video reveals many interesting facets about smiles.

Videos.name: Eyes
Videos.description: “The eyes are the windows to the soul”.  In fact, eye movements are so important to our species that humans have evolved the “white” area of the eyes to make our glances more conspicuous.  No other primates have these.

Videos.name: Arms and Hands
Videos.description: The arms and hands can convey all kinds of messages and this video explores them.

Videos.name: Body Language that Bothers Us
Videos.description: Almost any body language can bother us if it’s performed at the wrong time or in the wrong place. It's especially important to know what Desmond Morris describes as the 'Insult Signals'.

Videos.name: Catching Deceptive Body Language
Videos.description: People lie all the time — in big and small ways — for malicious and innocent reasons. But since most don’t tell sustained, deliberate lies humans are often clumsy in executing them.  It turns out there are ways to detect deceptive body language in others, and this video looks at them.

Videos.name: Meetings
Videos.description: It turns out there is even special body language taking place in meetings, as this video reveals.

Videos.name: Office Tactics
Videos.description: Sometimes things get heated at work. There may be stress, defensiveness or outright aggression. Whether it be meetings, job interviews, management reviews, or unplanned moments, we can all become more literate and tactical in decoding and de-escalating tense body language.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: In this final video of the course we'll recap on all the main takeaways from Understanding Body Language.

Courses.intro_description: Alfred Mehrabian’s work in the 1970’s reminds us that body language carries the greatest impact when we communicate with other humans — far more than our voice and the message 'script' itself.  In this course we'll examine these things, plus ways that body language shows up in real life at work, how body language can be subtle and deceptive, and how it relates to power and status.
Courses.name: Understanding Body Language
Courses.description: How to read others so you know what they’re thinking and feeling.

Headings.text: The demands of life grow more challenging
To meet them we must work on ourselves
Energy management is a vital skill
To find ideas to make your soul sing
About the four sources of energy
A high performing more engaged you

Videos.name: Introduction to Physical Energy
Videos.description: Physical energy is the most fundamental source of all our energy. It’s the root of our alertness and vitality. It allows us to think creatively, to manage emotions, to perform even basic tasks. The importance of Physical Energy is often overlooked by leaders and managers in business who expect their staff to work long hours at peak performance...

Videos.name: Sleep
Videos.description: Everyone knows that sleep is important, but how much do you actually need? And what impact does getting too little have on your performance, productivity and engagement? This video explores...

Videos.name: Hydration
Videos.description: Recent research estimates that 75% of Americans are chronically dehydrated most of the time. That’s pretty shocking when you consider the effect dehydration has on your body, mind and energy.

Videos.name: Diet
Videos.description: At the most basic level, physical energy comes from the interaction between Oxygen and Glucose. Our glucose levels at any given time depend on what we last ate, when we ate it and what our levels of physical exertion currently are.  But it’s not just about the quantity, but the quality of the foods we all eat.

Videos.name: Exercise
Videos.description: In most jobs our bodies have been completely cut out of the equation of performance. We spend most of the time sitting down, sometimes not leaving the office until the end of the working day. When leaders and managers don’t appreciate the importance of exercise and movement in the day, they overlook a primary opportunity to help people to perform at their best.

Videos.name: Breathing
Videos.description: Most of us take breathing for granted, and we don’t give it much thought. But when it comes to being energised and controlling that energised state, breathing is one of our most powerful resources.  In fact, about 90% of our energy is supported by oxygen in the air we breathe. It oxidises our food, converting it into energy.  You can see that breathing is important!

Videos.name: Interval Resting
Videos.description: Marathon runners know that to run faster, you need to run slower. What that means is that if you start runs more slowly and use your energy efficiently, you’ll have more energy when you need it towards the end. By running slower at times, your overall runs become faster.  The same applies at work.  If you rest more, you’ll get more done.

Videos.name: Morning Routine
Videos.description: How you start your day has a profound influence on how productive you’re going to be. Most of us start off in an entirely reactive way. We feel groggy, we hit snooze, we slope out of bed and tell ourselves we just need some sugar or caffeine. We leave the house grumpy, rushed, distracted and unfocussed.  Surely there's a better way?

Videos.name: Introduction to Emotional Energy
Videos.description: Do you know someone who’ll find a reason to get upset, regardless of what happens to them? Conversely, do you know people find a positive to focus on and be happy, regardless of what they experience or feel? How we manage our emotions has a profound impact on how fulfilled and happy we are. Positive emotions drive an amazing level of energy within us.

Videos.name: Positive Energy Rituals
Videos.description: Too few of our clients allow themselves the time to simply enjoy things for their own sake. How often in your daily life do you experience joy or deep satisfaction? How many hours a week do you set aside for the pleasurable activities and the recovery they provide? When was the last time you completely disconnected and let go?

Videos.name: Negative Emotions
Videos.description: Negative emotions can be useful: they help us evaluate our experience. But From an energy perspective negative emotions are exhausting. Carrying negative emotions around with us is like going for a long hike wearing a heavy backpack. Your energy will run out far more quickly than it would if you weren’t carrying anything.

Videos.name: Relationships
Videos.description: Managing emotional energy can seem trickier and more complex than managing physical energy. Healthy friendships can be an excellent source of positive energy and renewal.

Videos.name: Self Confidence
Videos.description: Many of our coaching clients want to feel more confident. Whether it’s the senior leader with imposter syndrome or the successful person with doubts about their abilities, we’ve all felt it at some point. Lacking confidence is like an all-pervading illness, and many of us hope for something like a magic pill to make us better...

Videos.name: Self Control
Videos.description: We place far too much value on discipline and willpower. We think that exercising self- control, trying harder or being more focused will somehow help us achieve what we want. But there’s a major flaw in that thinking. We use up our energy reserves for self-control very quickly. The less we need to rely on those energy reserves the better.

Videos.name: Listening Skills
Videos.description: Communication skills are vitally important and influence every part of your life. Of all those communication skills, listening is the most important.

Videos.name: Empathy
Videos.description: People often get stuck in their own agendas at work. Some pride themselves on being headstrong and focused in order to get stuff done. The downside is that while they’re doing it, others can end up feeling undervalued, demeaned and unheard. Empathy doesn’t come naturally to all of us but is like a muscle that can be developed and built on over time.

Videos.name: Introduction to Mental Energy
Videos.description: If there's one thing we all notice at the end of a long day at the office, it’s how we can struggle to hold a thought in our heads or function efficiently. This is normally due to mental fatigue.

Videos.name: Optimism
Videos.description: What’s it like to work with optimists? Some of you watching this will say, ‘it’s great’. Some of you will roll your eyes and say ‘it can be a struggle’. Both answers are correct –  but for different reasons.

Videos.name: Mental Preparation
Videos.description: Some say that the factors determining our success in life are 80% psychological and only 20% physical. How you think about something will have an enormous influence over whether you actually achieve it.

Videos.name: Visualisation
Videos.description: Visualisation is a powerful tool. It can help us create absolute certainty about an outcome. The confidence and empowerment we get from positive visualisation helps to invigorate our mental energy.

Videos.name: Positive Self-Talk
Videos.description: What is self-talk? It’s that voice that chats to you inside your head. And it’s probably telling you right now that you don’t have a voice that chats inside your head. That’s what we call self-talk.

Videos.name: Effective Time Management
Videos.description: Managing our energy, not our time, is the key to high performance. Time management is not a goal in itself. Instead, it serves the pursuit of effective energy management.

Videos.name: Creativity
Videos.description: Our brains use up a great deal of energy. Though it comprises only 2% of our body’s mass the brain uses up an astonishing 25% of its oxygen. The more time we spend in sustained conscious thought without taking a break, the more susceptible we’ll be to lapses in judgment. In business we tend to exhaust our mental energies on a daily basis.

Videos.name: Introduction to Spiritual Energy
Videos.description: We’re not referring to specific religious beliefs here, which some, but not all of us may hold, but to something far more general and fundamental. Spiritual energy is about our connection to a deeply held set of values and to a purpose that transcends our own self-interest.

Videos.name: Passion
Videos.description: The most successful people tend to be those most passionate about their work and their lives as a whole. They’re not necessarily the most talented; it’s their passion that gives them the strength to succeed when others give up.

Videos.name: Integrity
Videos.description: Our spiritual energy drives us at a profound level. It’s what motivates us and what encourages us in our determination to succeed.

Videos.name: Honesty
Videos.description: If integrity is about reliability and doing what you say you’ll do, then honesty is about telling the truth, to others and to ourselves.

Videos.name: Values
Videos.description: If we live in alignment with our most deeply held values, then we’re fuelling our growth and development. But too often, the decisions we make are barely decisions at all. They're emotional reactions to what we’re experiencing, and often serve to fill some momentary emotional deficit.

Videos.name: Purpose
Videos.description: We all face extraordinary demands on our time and our energy. Few of us are content to be ordinary, in our work, our marriages, as parents, as children, or within our communities.  That's why we need deeply held values, to drive our purpose.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: You’ve watched the videos. Now here are some action points, based on the four energies we’ve explored in the course: Physical, Emotional, Mental, Spiritual.

Courses.intro_description: We have huge demands placed upon us in our daily lives, inside & outside work, many of them self-imposed. The challenges we now face are far greater than could have been anticipated even 10 years ago.  We do various things to meet these increasing demands, not all of them very healthy. This course is about pursuing being the best human being you can be.
Courses.name: Personal Effectiveness and Wellbeing
Courses.description: Wellbeing is all about energy. Harness your natural energy to improve every aspect of your life.

Headings.text: Memory: a most powerful & underused tool
Tips and techniques for improving it
About the two main categories of memory
You, remembering names, dates, facts & figures
You, presenting and fielding questions fearlessly
You, being perceived as more of an expert
You, being perceived as more of a leader

Videos.name: Long Term Memory
Videos.description: There are two main categories of memory: long-term and short-term. Here we start with long term memory.

Videos.name: Short Term Memory
Videos.description: Now we come to Short-term memory.  It's is fleeting in duration, yet it’s absolutely critical to remembering anything.

Videos.name: Acquisition, Storage and Retrieval
Videos.description: There are three phases to remembering:  Acquisition, Storage and Retrieval and we look at all three in this video.

Videos.name: Non-mnemonic Tools
Videos.description: Before we dive into the more advanced memory techniques, it's worth looking at some simpler ways of remembering things.

Videos.name: Introduction to Mnemonics
Videos.description: Brains are great at remembering certain things: bizarre images, strange stories, unique sounds. But they’re terrible when it comes to memorising data, numbers or words without context. Mnemonics are used by memory champions to perform seemingly impossible feats like memorising pages from a phonebook or reciting the order of a shuffled deck of cards...

Videos.name: Remembering Names
Videos.description: Do you forget names easily? Many people are honest enough to admit they do. Unfortunately, names are some of the most important things to remember if we want to build trust with our colleagues and clients.  This video looks at the three steps to remembering names.

Videos.name: Lists in Sequence
Videos.description: Another mnemonic tool is the use of association chains.

Videos.name: Lists Out of Sequence
Videos.description: In the previous video we looked at memorising lists using association chains.  That technique is great for memorising a sequence, but it won't help you to remember which item lies in which position on the list...

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: All the mnemonic tools outlined in this course can give a huge boost to your memory. But most of them will take a bit of work. Try and apply them whenever you can. For example, at a networking event, see if you can remember ten new names using the techniques we’ve suggested. Or the next time you go shopping try and chain the items together in your mind...

Courses.intro_description: This course is about helping you utilise one of the most powerful but underused tools you possess – your memory.  The ability to remember names, dates, facts and figures is hugely important at work. Some of the things having a great memory can help you with also include: relationships, confidence, reputation and health.
Courses.name: Mastering Your Memory
Courses.description: Remember almost anything with these simple techniques.

Headings.text: Discover the classic causes of conflicts
Always doing what's right can be a challenge
That can bring great benefits to a business
About the enemies of ethical behavioiur
Better decisions made, & in less time
Employees remaining loyal to the business

Videos.name: Introduction to Common Individual Mistakes
Videos.description: Here we’re going to look at common individual mistakes. We’ll focus on areas of Personal conduct and Decision-making. This video takes a real, practical example from sport and then relates it to business.

Videos.name: Intimidation
Videos.description: Tempers sometimes flare.  Patience can wear thin. Because people can be infuriating. And when we’re working under pressure, we may be guilty of the occasional angry outburst. But these outbursts need to be the exception. Aggression should never be a used as a tactic to get a result.

Videos.name: Social Proof
Videos.description: Social Proof is one of our habits of thinking. It’s a cognitive bias that we talk about in our Critical Thinking course. We also saw it in the introduction to this section, where Lance Armstrong persuaded his team that doping is acceptable because everyone else is doing it.

Videos.name: Comments and Jokes
Videos.description: You can’t talk about work all day. And you shouldn’t. Any group of people needs to share thoughts, feelings, ideas and jokes. It helps us bond, and we work better together a result.  The trouble is, you can take it too far without thinking.

Videos.name: Digital Communication
Videos.description: Everything you post is permanent. Every word, every picture, every exclamation mark and emoji. Even when you have the option to delete something you’ve written, the chances are that it’s still sitting on a server somewhere. And it may have been shared a million times already.

Videos.name: Conflicts of Interest
Videos.description: When you’re at work, you’re being paid to act in the interests of your client, or your employer, and your decisions should represent what’s best for them.  A conflict of interest occurs when you have two different interests to serve.

Videos.name: Enemies of Ethical Behaviour - Financial Gain
Videos.description: People know the difference between right and wrong. We all agree that lying, cheating, stealing or harming other people is bad. So why do people end up behaving badly?  And what can happen when money enters the equation?

Videos.name: Enemies of Ethical Behaviour - Self Image
Videos.description: Self-image is a big factor in our decision-making and the desire to be seen in a certain way can be the seed of ethical failure.

Videos.name: Introduction to Best Practice
Videos.description: You don’t need to make every decision yourself, starting from scratch. You need some generally agreed upon rules, guidelines and goals to refer to.  That’s why in every profession there are standards of Best Practice. Best Practice means doing more than the minimum.

Videos.name: Competition
Videos.description: Competition is the cornerstone of the market. Every player in the market will compete with every other.  So how do we make healthy competition more likely?

Videos.name: Diversity and Inclusion - What it is
Videos.description: A diverse workforce contains different kinds of people. It should reflect the society from which it’s drawn. Why should we have this as a goal?

Videos.name: Diversity and Inclusion - How to Do it
Videos.description: In the last video we defined Diversity and said why it was important to have a diverse workforce. In this video we talk more about ‘how?’.

Videos.name: Transparency and Openness
Videos.description: Now, let’s look at how, in good times and bad, Open communication is essential to your ability to do business.

Videos.name: Fairness
Videos.description: Professor Joel Brockner of Columbia Business School has a great real world example of the importance of fairness. He tells a story that illustrates what he calls ‘Process Fairness’.  It goes like this...

Videos.name: Economics vs. Ethics
Videos.description: Here’s a strange thing. In business, we can be as selfish as we like.  Or at least according to Adam Smith, the founder of Economic Theory...

Videos.name: Accountability
Videos.description: This video provides a case study in accountability to illustrate that it's about thinking outside the cycle of blame and self-defence.

Videos.name: Broadcasting Your Values
Videos.description: Your values are what you do, not what you say.  People perceive your values in your day-to-day interactions – and even more at the important moments, where there’s lot at stake.

Videos.name: Introduction to Making Decisions
Videos.description: In this section we’re going to describe a scenario and examine it from 4 different perspectives.

Videos.name: Consequences
Videos.description: First we’ll try to make our decision based on the consequences, which probably sounds like an obvious basis for making a decision, but we’ll soon see that it’s not always so simple.

Videos.name: Rules
Videos.description: In the last video we saw how assessing the consequences of your actions can be a risky way of making a decision. Now let’s look at it through the lens of setting Rules.

Videos.name: Character
Videos.description: Thinking again about that takeover we’ve been discussing… another way to come at the problem is to think about character – or brand.  We ask: am I the sort of person who does this? Or… what sort of person does this make me?

Videos.name: Feelings
Videos.description: Now let’s see how feelings can be a guide to making the best decision. This video suggests some questions you might ask yourself.

Videos.name: Conclusion
Videos.description: In this section we’ve tried to show how Business Ethics, like any ethics, are complicated, especially once you’re out there in the real world, being pulled ten ways at once.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: This final video looks back over what we’ve done and summarises the main advice.

Courses.intro_description: According to one of the founders of modern management consultancy, Peter Drucker: 'There is neither a separate ethics of business nor is one needed'.  In other words, Business Ethics is the same as any other ethics.  It’s about doing the right thing.  But working out which is the right thing to do, and sticking to it, is not always easy.
Courses.name: Ethics for Business
Courses.description: Enhance your reputation by doing the right thing.

Headings.text: Workplace conflict is a major fear for many
Discover the classic causes of conflict…
That cultural differences can be a cause
Conflict can stem from unconscious bias
How the four personality types interact
How to defuse your own stress
An ability to reframe your own mindset
By being prepared you remain more in control

Videos.name: Culture - Part 1
Videos.description: The first step to overcoming a conflict is to truly understand all of its root causes. In this video, we’ll start looking at cultural differences.  In today’s ever-expanding global business world, conflicts connected with cultural difference are on the increase. From culture to culture, accepted behaviours, and thus expected behaviours, differ wildly.

Videos.name: Culture - Part 2
Videos.description: How would you feel if your boss called you into his or her office and said, “Listen, we need to talk about your persistent lateness? Your colleagues are annoyed, we’re missing deadlines and it makes the firm look bad”.  Of course, it depends on where you're from...

Videos.name: Values, Opinions and Beliefs - Part 1
Videos.description: Now we’re going to examine the role that cultural differences in values, opinions and beliefs have in causing conflicts.  Universally accepted, but unequally prioritised values can create strong conflicts between and among individuals and groups.

Videos.name: Values, Opinions and Beliefs - Part 2
Videos.description: Have you ever been in a meeting and wanted to comment or ask a question but hesitated to do so? Or, conversely, ever expressed a solution in a meeting that everyone seemed to agree with at the time, and then been annoyed when dissenting feedback started to trickle in afterwards?

Videos.name: Unconscious Bias - Part 1
Videos.description: Conflict can also stem from our unconscious biases. In the next two videos, we’ll examine four typical biases that can create and or exacerbate conflicts, and discuss how to combat them.

Videos.name: Unconscious BIas - Part 2
Videos.description: This video looks at a workplace conflict caused by unconscious bias.

Videos.name: Personality Styles - Part 1
Videos.description: Everybody’s different, aren’t they? Well, yes and no. It’s helpful, especially when you’re trying to avoid workplace conflict, to think about different types of personality.

Videos.name: Personality Styles - Part 2
Videos.description: Unlike Drivers and Analytical's, Amiable's and Expressive's prefer to display emotions openly and focus on relationships over logic at work.

Videos.name: Uncontrollable Factors
Videos.description: The cyclical nature of business causes periodic swings from high profits and development to big losses, inevitable lay-offs and organisational change. It can make employees feel isolated and uncertain about their future, stressed and ripe for conflict. It’s hard to stay positive when you’re faced with being laid off.

Videos.name: Breathe
Videos.description: Recent studies have proven what yogis have known for 2,500 years. That slow breathing, 4-7 breaths per minute, can greatly reduce stress and inhibit fight or flight responses in your amygdala. Both are essential to maintaining your balance in a conflict.

Videos.name: Introduction to Meditation
Videos.description: Recent University of Massachusetts research has proved how beneficial meditation can be. Meditation helps you increase grey matter concentration in the brain regions involved in self-awareness, empathy, emotional regulation, learning and memory. All these areas are essential for maintaining objectivity and balance when trying to resolve a conflict

Videos.name: Guided Meditation
Videos.description: In this video we take you on a guided meditation...

Videos.name: Question Your Thoughts
Videos.description: Are you a slave to your thoughts? Or do you have the power to control them?   Get used to challenging your thoughts. Are they objectively true? Are there some you could fruitfully discard? Doing so will help you maintain a more objective mindset. And that’s critical to successfully resolving a conflict.

Videos.name: Prepare to be Derailed
Videos.description: Have you ever been surprised by the other party’s counter argument when you’re attempting to resolve a conflict?  When caught out like this, your fight or flight mechanism reacts and your emotions take over.

Videos.name: Determine Your Resolution Approach
Videos.description: Choosing the right style and approach for a difficult discussion will boost your chances of success. Think about your desired outcome and determine which of the following five styles would work best.

Videos.name: Manage Your Body and Voice
Videos.description: Use positive body language and remember the power of your voice. It will help improve your status and confidence, and it’s incredibly helpful when resolving conflicts.

Videos.name: Active Listening
Videos.description: Active or empathic listening is another great way to build trust and show the other party that you’re a partner working towards a common objective.

Videos.name: Build and Maintain Rapport
Videos.description: It may sound simplistic, but the most effective way to keep both your own and the other party’s emotions in check, is to maintain your relationship while you’re resolving the conflict.

Videos.name: Identify the Needs
Videos.description: In order to influence effectively, you must first identify, then understand each other’s real needs. A solution will only work if it addresses those needs, rather than denying them.

Videos.name: PAUSE Method
Videos.description: We may react to a perceived attack by immediately defending ourselves. Unfortunately, this reaction is highly unlikely to help resolve a conflict.

Videos.name: Stick to the Facts
Videos.description: Sticking to the facts when resolving a conflict is vital to a successful outcome. It will help you use objective rather than subjective language.  And it will stop you expressing opinions, emotions & feelings that might otherwise derail the conversation.

Videos.name: Using Positive Language
Videos.description: What’s the difference between saying “You constantly undermine my authority in front of my team!” and “I’d prefer it if you discussed these types of issues with me in private'. The first is an emotionally charged attack and the second is an assertive request that includes a potential solution.

Videos.name: Using a Neutral Party
Videos.description: If you’re not sure you'll be able to maintain objectivity in the midst of a conflict resolution, using a neutral third party can help.  A neutral party will provide an objective perspective, and will be able to focus the needs, desires, or concerns that underly each side’s position.

Videos.name: Conflict Resolution, Not Opponent Destruction
Videos.description: The last two videos focus on a couple of final things for you to remember before attempting to resolve a conflict.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: In conclusion, this video has some last thoughts to round off this course.  Always remember that conflict does have a positive side.  It can promote collaboration, improve performance, foster creativity and innovation, and build deeper relationships...

Courses.intro_description: Too many conflicts – in the workplace and elsewhere – are inflamed because the opposing parties are attempting to overpower each other.  Conflict resolution, on the other hand, is about addressing the key interests of each side and meeting some of their needs. It’s about winning the other side over, rather than defeating them.
Courses.name: Conflict Resolution
Courses.description: Learn to win the other side over without defeating them.
Courses.strapline: Meet the needs of both sides.

Headings.text: To help you 'manage' whoever manages you
To produce greater outcomes for you both
To become the solution to your own success
How to establish ground rules that work
How to build a relationship with your boss
A more productive relationship with your boss
You, going on to achieve far more
You, creating positive change in your team

Videos.name: Get To Know Your Boss
Videos.description: If there’s a golden rule to communication it’s this: Communication has nothing to do with you, and everything to do with your audience.  Managing Up is no different.  To achieve this, you must first get to know your boss.

Videos.name: Imagine the Bigger Picture
Videos.description: When we’re stuck in our day-to-day work, it’s easy to get frustrated by our relationships with people in management roles. They can seem remote, or simply uninterested in the minutiae of our daily concerns...

Videos.name: Establish Ground Rules
Videos.description: Bruce Tulgan, author of “It’s Okay to Manage Your Boss', believes the secret of Managing Up is in establishing ground rules as soon as possible.

Videos.name: Check-in on Your Priorities
Videos.description: It can be incredibly useful for you and your manager to check in on what your priorities are and how this should affect the way you spend your working hours.

Videos.name: Find Out What Works
Videos.description: We’re all different. In the way we think, connect and communicate. So it’s important to understand which method of communication and way of working is most appropriate with your manager.

Videos.name: Top Questions for your Manager
Videos.description: Learning more about how your manager works and what they’re looking to achieve can be of huge benefit when Managing Up.  Get to know your manager’s preferences for taking in information, making decisions, structuring their day, and communicating with others.

Videos.name: Get Specific
Videos.description: 'Could you take care of this?' the simple and oh so common request that's as vague as it's infuriating.  And what’s his or her response when you ask your manager these questions: 'Wait, how, exactly, do you want me to accomplish this?  By what time on what day?  Do you want me to stop doing the other thing you gave me so I can start doing this?'

Videos.name: Share Your Ideas
Videos.description: If you have the confidence to share your ideas with your manager at the appropriate moments, it can have a long lasting impact. It plays an integral role in implementing change, and can be of great benefit when Managing Up.

Videos.name: What to Avoid
Videos.description: When managing up there are many pitfalls to be aware of. Here are three of the most common, and the most important.

Videos.name: Amplification
Videos.description: In the last video, we discussed the importance of not trying to manipulate the views of your manager by way of flattery, but instead, aiming for something more genuine and results driven.

Videos.name: Be the Solution
Videos.description: We should always strive to be the person who takes the lead on a new project, or who handles a problem or difficulty; the first person our manager turns to when in need.

Videos.name: Build on their Strengths
Videos.description: Leaders are often encouraged to focus on their employees’ strengths rather than their weaknesses, because it yields better results. Doing the same when managing up will have a similar outcome.

Videos.name: Avoid Being Overloaded
Videos.description: Your manager will need dedication and commitment from you in your role. In return, they should be aware of what’s possible, making sure not overload you with an unrealistic schedule.

Videos.name: Build Your Network
