Videos.description: Don’t shy away from seeking help when Managing Up. Instead, take any opportunity to develop a network of people who can be a positive influence on you and your career.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: This is the final video of the course, but for you, it’s just the beginning.  The work really starts now. This video re-caps on all the key learning points...

Courses.intro_description: A recent study overwhelmingly declared that “People don’t leave jobs, they leave managers'.  Bad management can take away any enjoyment or passion felt for a particular role; they can leave you feeling undervalued and frustrated.  Knowing how to combat such behaviour is sadly an ever growing need, with many in management roles thrown in the deep end: good at their jobs, not so good with their people.
Courses.name: Managing Up
Courses.description: What do you want from your boss? Build a great relationship that works for you both.
Courses.strapline: Learn to work with your boss.

Headings.text: There are pros and cons to delegating
Who should you trust to delegate to?
Your relationship with time is important…
It impacts your deployment of other's time
A formula for choosing the right people
About the value & use of cognitive empathy
The right people assigned to the right tasks

Videos.name: Defining Delegation
Videos.description: In Jeanne Baer’s 'You Can’t Do It All: Effective Delegation for Supervisors', Delegation is defined as: “Assigning a whole unit of work (a task from start to finish) to an employee who is capable of doing it.”

Videos.name: What are the Pros and Cons?
Videos.description: So you’ve defined your goals for this workshop. You’ve also defined Delegation and its relevance to you and your workplace.  Specifically, what are the upsides for the Delegator? For the employee? The team? region and/or company?  And what are the Cons, or the downsides, using the same process. .

Videos.name: Your Delegation Event
Videos.description: In the Working Voices Digital Influencing Skills course, we use Jack Canfield’s E+R=O framework to help focus more clearly on a given event, the ways that we react to those events, and the outcomes we hope to achieve by taking those actions.  Here we apply it to our Delegation Event.

Videos.name: Choosing the Right People
Videos.description: A good plan means little if it’s not also well executed — and people play the most critical role in Delegation.

Videos.name: The Will-Skill Matrix
Videos.description: As previously mentioned, some elements, including personnel, may be out of your control — but the ways in which you deploy and cultivate that talent is very much within your Circle of Influence.  This video introduces you to a useful tool called the “Will-Skill Matrix”.

Videos.name: Communicating your Delegation Plans - Part 1
Videos.description: With most on-the-job projects, there are two aspects that need to be considered: The What and The How.  The What is the task itself including the planning, meetings, goal setting — all of it.  The How is the ways in which you communicate and execute your plans.

Videos.name: Communicating your Delegation Plans - Part 2
Videos.description: In 'You Can’t Do It All: Effective Delegation for Supervisors', Jeanne Baer reminds us that when a manager or supervisor delegates well, he or she also does the following: Discusses the task in advance with the employee to be sure the task fits into the employee’s current schedule.

Videos.name: The SMART Framework - Part 1
Videos.description: We need to be organised and clear when communicating Delegation Plans.  That clarity and organisation will make it easier for the employee to absorb and act upon our information. It will also help us zoom-in on what’s essential.

Videos.name: The SMART Framework - Part 2
Videos.description: We’ve defined S.M.A.R.T. Goals.   Now, let’s use them.

Videos.name: The SMART Framework - Part 3
Videos.description: You’ve crafted a S.M.A.R.T. Goal for your Team’s overall Delegation Event.  Now let’s practice on specific individuals.

Videos.name: The SMART Framework - Part 4
Videos.description: We’ve organised your message using S.M.A.R.T. Goals.  Now let’s focus on delivering that plan.

Videos.name: Checklist
Videos.description: When practicing the delivery of your S.M.A.R.T. Goals, it’s often helpful to assess your work afterwords to evaluate progress.  Here's a checklist to help you.

Videos.name: Check-in
Videos.description: Before we move on to Time Management, this video checks in:  How’s it going, so far?  What’s clear?  What’s unclear?

Videos.name: Self Assessment
Videos.description: In this module, we’re not only talking about how to best deploy the talents of your employees in the time given, we’re also focusing on you — and your personal management of time.

Videos.name: Cognitive Empathy
Videos.description: Effective time management is effective people management. The more insight we have into our teams, the better equipped we’ll be to guide and deploy their talents.  When considering the human side of time management, let’s think about utilising cognitive empathy.

Videos.name: Employee Assessment
Videos.description: Utilising cognitive empathy, as discussed in our previous video, helps us to better understand our teams, business partners, and colleagues. It gives us insight into how they best work and process information.  With that in mind, let’s apply your self-assessment questions to employees and teams.

Videos.name: Establish & Maintain Time Controls
Videos.description: Now that we have a clearer idea of employee strengths and challenges, vis-à-vis time, let’s dust off our calendars or diaries and start scheduling.

Videos.name: Check-in and Review
Videos.description: Now that you’ve created a more detailed timeline for your delegation event, let’s zoom out for a moment and look at the big picture.  What is the exact start date for your event?  What’s the end date?  Where’s the precise mid-point?

Videos.name: Don't Forget About You
Videos.description: If all of our time management work is sounding like a lot, you’re right.  That’s why we also want to make sure that you’re managing YOUR time as effectively as possible. For starters, create time in your schedule to reflect on your delegation event.

Videos.name: Putting it All Together
Videos.description: In the delegation portion of this workshop, we promised to eventually drop in specific dates and times, so that you can clearly communicate the delegation event to your teams.  Now is that time.

Videos.name: Debrief
Videos.description: This marks the end of our time management module and this video recaps on everything we've considered.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: This is the final video of our Delegation & Time Management workshop. Congratulations on completion!  In our first video, you wrote down your goals for this course. What were they? Did you achieve them?

Courses.intro_description: This interactive and interconnected suite of videos is a hands-on workshop designed to help enhance your approaches to strategic planning and the communication of those plans.  “Hands-On” is key here.
Courses.name: Delegating and Time Management
Courses.description: Make time your friend by including other people.

Headings.text: Anger should be deployed rather than felt
How best to espress anger to others
Other ways to effectively deal with anger
You, being assertive rather than angry

Videos.name: What Causes Anger?
Videos.description: Because people experience anger in different ways, and for vastly different reasons, it can often be hard to understand and manage. What sets one person off might have no impact on you.

Videos.name: What's Happening in the Brain?
Videos.description: In order to begin to manage anger, it’s important that we understand what’s happening in our brains when we experience the kind of anger we find hard to control.

Videos.name: Assertiveness
Videos.description: People use various conscious and unconscious processes to deal with angry feelings.  The three main approaches are expression, suppression and calming; calming is similar to suppression in that its goal is to help you stay present without losing your temper.

Videos.name: Suppression
Videos.description: Suppression, essentially, is the process of pushing the feelings down. “Don’t think about it, focus on something positive!”

Videos.name: Calming
Videos.description: Calming is similar to suppression, in that it’s goal is to facilitate being able to stay present without blowing your stack.

Videos.name: Introduction to Prevention
Videos.description: Anger is an active emotion that calls the person feeling it to respond. As such, there are certain interpersonal and social skills necessary to maintain self-control. There are a number of ways that you can prevent anger from flaring up. To stop it before it even starts.

Videos.name: Interpersonal Communication
Videos.description: One of the best ways to manage anger before it even begins is to increase your interpersonal communication skills.

Videos.name: Emotional Intelligence
Videos.description: This video explores another key component of anger-prevention which is to increase your emotional intelligence.

Videos.name: What Happened vs. What You Made Up
Videos.description: Another key aspect of emotional intelligence is the ability to distinguish what happened from what we make up about what happened.

Videos.name: Creative Problem Solving
Videos.description: Not all anger is misplaced. Often, anger is a natural response to very real problems. That being said, not all problems have solutions. Because of this, it’s important to learn how better to handle problems, rather than to solve them.

Videos.name: Success Principles
Videos.description: In his book 'The Happiness Advantage' author Shawn Achor says, “When we are happy — when our mindset and mood are positive — we are smarter, more motivated, and thus more successful. Happiness is the centre and success revolves around it.”

Videos.name: Taming the Amygdala
Videos.description: The amygdala is that part of our brain responsible for 'fight or flight', and in cases where anger is a problem, it’s probably because you’ve gone into 'fight' mode without even thinking about it.

Videos.name: Introduction to Mindfulness
Videos.description: A mindfulness practice has been proven to decrease grey matter in the amygdala, and increase grey matter in other areas of the brain responsible for critical thinking, rational thought, and executive function.

Videos.name: Mindfulness Practices
Videos.description: There are many mindfulness practices available to try. Many of the more formal practices can take up to 40 minutes of meditation. However, here are many meditation apps available that can guide you through a practice that can range from 10 minutes on up.

Videos.name: Changing Your Thinking
Videos.description: Our thinking can create our feelings, as psychiatrist Aaron Beck discovered in the 1960s when he invented Cognitive Behavioural Therapy, or CBT.

Videos.name: Actions
Videos.description: This final video reminds us that anger, and anger management, has been a topic of conversation throughout the ages.

Courses.intro_description: According to the American Psychological Association, “Anger is a completely normal, usually healthy, human emotion. But when it gets out of control and turns destructive, it can lead to problems — problems at work, in your personal relationships and in the overall quality of your life”.
Courses.name: Anger Management
Courses.description: Anger doesn’t work, take control and use your emotions in a positive way.

Headings.text: You’ll Learn Who Is More Affected By Bias
You’ll Learn How To Help Reduce Bias Of Your Own
Learn to Make Your Workplace A Equitable Place
How To Identify Various Common Biases
The Ability To Identify Threats & Opportunities
The Ability To Change Your Thoughts & Behaviour

Videos.name: What is Bias?
Videos.description: According to research, every second, our brains process 11 million bits of information, but our conscious minds can only deal with around 45 of these data points...

Videos.name: Conscious v Unconscious Bias
Videos.description: Conscious bias is when a person is aware they’re choosing one way of working, or one solution or person over another.  But are they ready to review or change their choice?

Videos.name: The Difficulty with the Term Bias
Videos.description: When we talk about Bias in the workplace, it isn’t only towards people. In fact, we apply bias to many things...

Videos.name: Problems Overcoming Bias
Videos.description: Even when we become aware of how biases can affect our decision-making, and lead to unfairness, it can still be difficult to overcome them. Here we examine some of the problems…

Videos.name: Affinity Bias
Videos.description: Affinity Bias is when we favour people, or ideas that are similar or familiar to us. They think or look like us, or may have had similar experiences…

Videos.name: Beauty Bias
Videos.description: Beauty bias is the tendency to favour people we perceive as being more beautiful over those who don’t fit our concept of beauty.  We also tend to favour their ideas or products…

Videos.name: Confirmation Bias
Videos.description: When we think we know something, we seek to solidify our thoughts by looking for evidence to prove our point, opinion, or hypothesis. Our brains do this all the time unconsciously...

Videos.name: Conformity Bias
Videos.description: Conformity Bias is the name given to the phenomenon where we change our thoughts, preferences and beliefs to align with the people around us…

Videos.name: The Halo & The Horns
Videos.description: When someone performs well at something, we automatically increase our perception of that person’s value generally and this is the Halo Effect.  Its opposite is the Horns Effect…

Videos.name: Hindsight Bias
Videos.description: It’s very common for us to want to show our value or intelligence by retrospectively predicting what’s already happened, and this is known as Hindsight Bias...

Videos.name: Negativity & Positivity
Videos.description: Most of us are prone to Positivity or Negativity Bias and both cause the same level of distortion…

Videos.name: Opportunity Bias
Videos.description: Opportunity Bias causes us to give people credit for doing a great job when the truth might be that they were simply given a great job…

Videos.name: Status Quo Bias
Videos.description: Change is part of modern life in any modern organisation and often it happens very quickly; sometimes people will resist change or try to slow it down...

Videos.name: Statistical Bias
Videos.description: Statistical bias is not a bias in our minds so much as a bias in the way we collect information...but data only tells us what we ask it to tell us...

Videos.name: Stereotypical Bias
Videos.description: Everyone has skills and preferences, but it’s inaccurate and offensive to assume they match up to a person's ethnic, gender identity, sexual orientation or national culture…

Videos.name: Zero Sum Bias
Videos.description: Zero sum bias is the idea that if one person gets something, someone else always has to go without, and this bias is often flawed...

Videos.name: Systemic Bias
Videos.description: If a bias is shared by large numbers of people it becomes systemic, with the result that a whole organisation or society could become unbalanced on a particular issue…

Videos.name: Cumulative Bias
Videos.description: While a single bias might feel quite weak or niche on its own, what if multiple biases over time had favoured or disfavoured a person?

Videos.name: What Happens When we Minimise it?
Videos.description: if we got our biases under control we could look forward to better decisions, increased diversity and a more equitable work environment…

Videos.name: Overcoming Our Biases
Videos.description: On this course we’ve learnt about a handful of the most encountered biases, but what can we do to overcome them? In this video we provide six top tips…

Courses.intro_description: Bias is a powerful word and a natural, inevitable part of perception.  But we need to make sure we're not relying on thought patterns that exclude certain ideas or people…
Courses.name: Understanding Bias
Courses.description: Bias is a natural and inevitable part of perception.  This course explores and explains the most common kinds

Headings.text: HOW THE MEDIA INFLUENCES OUR THOUGHTS
HOW THE DIFFERENT TYPES IMPACT PEOPLE
THE ABILITY TO UNDERSTAND THE BENEFITS
THE ABILITY TO CHANGE YOUR THOUGHTS & BEHAVIOUR

Videos.name: What is Diversity?
Videos.description: Diversity is often viewed as existing in a few key themes such as genders, ethnicity or nationality, but these are just part of what makes up our Demographic diversity

Videos.name: Gender Identity
Videos.description: Gender is not a binary concept as there are many other gender identities, as you will discover here

Videos.name: Age
Videos.description: Most workplaces have a breadth of people of different ages working alongside each other. This is one type of diversity we can capitalise on, but often unconsciously forget

Videos.name: Ethnicity
Videos.description: Ethnicity is part of what makes the world as culturally diverse and rich as it is. It refers to an individual’s heritage and how they may culturally express themselves

Videos.name: Disability
Videos.description: According to the World Health Organisation, disability is an interaction between an individual's health condition and their personal and environmental factors

Videos.name: Mental Ill Health
Videos.description: We need to remember that everyone has mental health, and a person's mental health or mental fitness is something that is not always in a static state

Videos.name: Sensory
Videos.description: A sensory condition is where a person’s sensory functions do not work in a typical way.  Not all sensory disabilities are the same and will affect different individuals in diverse ways

Videos.name: Learning Disabilities
Videos.description: Learning disabilities are where someone has a reduced intellectual ability to the extent it impacts daily activities such as household tasks, personal care or managing their finances

Videos.name: Physical Disability
Videos.description: It’s estimated that 130 million people at a global level are wheelchair users, but not everyone with a physical disability needs a wheelchair

Videos.name: Neurological Disability
Videos.description: Neurological conditions can affect a person from birth (such as epilepsy) or develop slowly over time (dementia).  These conditions present symptoms in a range of ways

Videos.name: Neurodivergence
Videos.description: Neurodivergence is when someone’s brain learns, behaves and processes information in a way which is not societally considered as “typical”

Videos.name: Sexual and Romantic Orientation - Context
Videos.description: Most of us know friends, family members or colleagues who are Lesbian, Gay or Bisexual, but these are just three of the letters making up the acronym 'LGBT+'

Videos.name: Sexual and Romantic Orientation - Terminology
Videos.description: This video offers some quick explanations of the common terms used to describe sexual and romantic orientations in modern life.  Some you may be familiar with, some less so

Videos.name: Religious Beliefs
Videos.description: For some people, their religion has meant that they and their families have been persecuted or discriminated against for centuries, depending on where they live

Videos.name: Our Appearance
Videos.description: Our psychology is hard coded. Even when we don’t want to, we may be assessing all the different elements of someone’s appearance to place them into particular categories

Videos.name: In person vs remote workers
Videos.description: Those working remotely may feel like part of an out-group meaning their ideas for improvements are less likely to be considered compared to their office based peers

Videos.name: Intersectionality
Videos.description: Many people who are diverse compared to the majority within the organisations they work for, may actually straddle two or more different facets of diversity

Videos.name: Accents
Videos.description: In a global working world, our ability to be judged by those around us from just a few words is huge but can have a big part to play in an individual’s success at work

Courses.intro_description: While some organisations have been looking at Diversity for years, recent events have brought it to the forefront in most organisations across the world
Courses.name: Understanding Demographic Diversity
Courses.description: Most people have heard the term ‘Diversity’ in their workplace over the past few years; but what does the word actually mean?  This course explores some of its many facets.

Headings.text: GREATER DIVERSITY IS GOOD FOR BUSINESS
GREATER DIVERSITY LEADS TO GREATER OPPORTUNITY
HOW THE MEDIA INFLUENCES OUR THOUGHTS
AND HOW THE DIFFERENT ASPECTS IMPACT PEOPLE
YOU CAN CHANGE YOUR THOUGHTS & BEHAVIOURS
YOUR WORKPLACE WILL BE FAIRER & MORE EQUAL

Videos.name: Introverts vs Extroverts
Videos.description: Not everything is visible or easily understood. Some people will work brilliantly in a group and really thrive off that energy; Some will find it harder because of how they are wired

Videos.name: Diversity  of  Experience
Videos.description: Some may say that diversity of experience is possibly the broadest of all the different diversity characteristics.  Part of this will come from the opportunities you had when growing up

Videos.name: Diversity of Opportunity
Videos.description: One of the critical failures that organisations tend to have when looking to bring people into their company is that they only consider what people have done in the past

Videos.name: Diversity of Network
Videos.description: One of the biggest challenges we face is our natural pull or affinity bias towards people who look like us, think like us or share the same experiences as ours

Videos.name: The  Global  Perspective
Videos.description: When organisations undertake Diversity and Inclusion initiatives, this is mainly done from the political viewpoint of the Global North, rather than viewed with a more global perspective

Videos.name: Binary or Continuum?
Videos.description: In societies in general, we are seeing more polarisation of viewpoints that can sometimes feel incredibly divisive.  Like so much in our lives, these aren’t ultimately yes or no issues

Videos.name: What makes Diversity difficult to talk about - Part 1?
Videos.description: Improving diversity seems to make a lot of sense. However, the reality is we often shy away from the conversation for several reasons, as you'll discover

Videos.name: What makes Diversity difficult to talk about - Part 2?
Videos.description: This video continues to explore why we often shy away from conversations that explore improving diversity

Videos.name: Diversity in our Media
Videos.description: Throughout history, all forms of communication have tended towards storytelling because most of the stories are told from the perspective of people of a certain demographic

Videos.name: The Future of Diversity and AI
Videos.description: With the increasing rise in focus on Diversity and Inclusion in our workplaces, organisations are finding new ways of using technology to provide more equity for those who are underrepresented

Videos.name: The importance of Diversity
Videos.description: We can view diversity’s contribution through a number of perspectives including a broad range of positive contributions, as well as ways that can have a negative impact

Videos.name: The Cases for Diversity
Videos.description: There are many reasons for us to harness the benefits that a diverse environment can bring, but why is it that others cannot always see our perspective?

Videos.name: Helpful Behaviours we can use to Encourage Diversity - Part 1
Videos.description: Finally we’d like to suggest some practical applications that will be helpful across all dimensions of Diversity

Videos.name: Helpful Behaviours we can use to Encourage Diversity - Part 2
Videos.description: More practical applications that will be helpful across all dimensions of Diversity

Courses.intro_description: The other side of diversity is our Cognitive Diversity. This is formed from a range of elements that help us to understand, process and have the core values that we do
Courses.name: Understanding Cognitive Diversity
Courses.description: Cognitive Diversity is formed from a range of elements that help us to understand, process, have the core values and make us think of the world as we do.
